Graphical abstract Oxygen electrode catalysts are important as inter-conversion of O2 and H2O is crucial for energy technologies. However, the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR and OER) are a hindrance to their scalable production, whereas scarce and costly Pt and Ir/Ru-based catalysts with the highest electrocatalytic activity are commercially unviable. Since good ORR catalysts are not always efficient for OER and vice versa, so bifunctional catalysts on which OER and ORR occurs on the same electrode are very desirable. Alternative catalysts based on heteroatom-doped carbon nanomaterials, though showed good electrocatalytic activity yet their high cost and complex synthesis is not viable for scalable production. To overcome these drawbacks, biomass-derived heteroatom-doped porous carbons have recently emerged as low-cost, earth-abundant, renewable and sustainable environment-friendly materials for bifunctional oxygen catalysts. The tunable morphology, mesoporous structure and high concentration of catalytic active sites of these materials due to heteroatom (N)-doping could further enhance their ORR and OER activity, along with tolerance to methanol crossover and good durability. Thus, biomass-derived heteroatom-doped porous carbons with large surface area, rich edge defects, numerous micropores and thin 2D nanoarchitecture could be suitable as efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts. In the present article, synthesis, N-doping, ORR/OER mechanism and electrocatalytic performance of biomass-derived bifunctional catalysts has been discussed. The selected biomass (chitin, eggs, euonymus japonicas, tobacco, lysine and plant residue) except wood, act as both C and N precursor, resulting in N self-doping of porous carbons that avoids the use of toxic chemicals, thus making the synthesis a facile and environment-friendly green process. The synthetic strategy could be further optimized to develop future biomass-based N self-doped porous carbons as metal-free high performance bifunctional oxygen catalysts for commercial energy applications. Recent advances and the importance of biomass-based bifunctional oxygen catalysts in metal-air batteries and fuel cells has been highlighted. The material design, perspectives and future directions in this field are also provided. Keywords Bifunctional catalysts Biomass ORR OER N-doping Porous carbons 1 Introduction Fossil fuel exhaustion, energy security and climate change have prompted a renewed focus on energy harvesting from renewable sources. The availability of renewable energy resources, however, is a major challenge as it mismatches the demand [1] that has triggered an urgent need for potential portable devices to develop alternative storage devices with high energy density. Energy storage and conversion (ESC) technologies involving regenerative fuel cells (RFCs) and rechargeable metal-air batteries (MABs) is currently a hot topic in this field [2–6]. It is therefore essential to develop environmentally friendly, low-cost, efficient, sustainable, and renewable electrochemical ESC technologies to address the problems of environmental degradation, the energy crisis and global climate change [7,8]. Oxygen electrode catalysts are very important for renewable energy technologies because the interconversion of O2 and H2O plays a critical role [9]. The current key bottleneck that hinders their commercial production is the sluggish kinetics of ORR at the cathode that significantly reduces energy efficiency in fuel cells (FCs) and MABs, while OER is the anode reaction that plays a critical role in solar fuel synthesis and MABs. Because of multi-electron transfer in both ORR and OER, the sluggish kinetics of reactions hinder the commercial use of Zn-air batteries [10] and both reactions may be combined in an RFC that can serve as both a FC and a water electrolyzer [11]. In a variety of ESC devices (FCs, MABs, and water electrolyzers), ORR and OER occur (Fig. 1 ) and the produced renewable energy is generally low-cost, clean and efficient [12]. These higher efficiency and high energy density devices will drastically minimize the emission of CO2 and other pollutants compared to fossil fuel combustion gases [3,13]. Thus, electrochemical ORR and OER are crucial for a number of air-based sustainable energy generation, storage, and conversion technologies, but their limited overall performance because of sluggish oxygen reactions should be properly addressed [14]. Since the OER (charge) and ORR (discharge) take place on the same electrode in these devices, so they are called “bifunctional”, but the commercial usage of ESC devices is limited due to the non-availability of efficient bifunctional oxygen electrodes that should be stable over a wide potential range [5,15]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop novel and economical bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts that are highly efficient, long-term durable, eco-friendly and have excellent catalytic activity [16]. Bifunctional oxygen catalysts are very challenging since good OER catalysts are not necessarily good as ORR catalysts, and vice versa [15–17]. Their activity is strongly composition-dependent, and efficient materials for bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts may be composites containing multi-active centers. Thus, higher activity could be achieved by regulating their composition and properties, resulting in more efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts. The different binding strength of intermediate species of OER and ORR is however, one major challenge in this regard, leading to materials with high OER activity but low ORR activity and vice versa [4,18,19]. However, bifunctional catalysts should be able to perform under reverse (OER/ORR) conditions for practical devices. Current bifunctional oxygen catalysts are predominantly based on noble metals, alloys/composites of noble metals, pyrochlores, oxides/hydroxides of transition metals, perovskites, chalcogenides, carbonaceous materials, composites of carbon with metal/metal-oxide [18,20] and single atoms [21]. However, precious metal-based materials (RuO2, IrO2, and Pt) show excellent electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 1) and are capable of reducing overpotentials, but their inadequacy, higher cost and inefficient simultaneous OER and ORR activities limit their scalable use and therefore require alternative high-efficiency, economical, and earth-abundant materials to be used as bifunctional electrocatalysts [15,22–25]. The higher cost and sluggish kinetics of current catalysts led to metal-free heteroatom-doped carbons with higher catalytic activity and durability, as the bifunctional oxygen catalysts [26–28]. Despite good performance, their higher cost and complex synthesis is not feasible for commercial production and scalable use in practical ESC devices. This led to a new strategy involving the use of abundantly available biomass for the synthesis of bifunctional oxygen catalysts with higher catalytic efficiency [15,29]. For ORR, mesoporous biomass-derived carbon materials are distinct, although the simultaneous OER and ORR catalytic activity of biomass-based carbon materials is not yet widely explored [30,31]. Extrinsic doping of heteroatoms that modulates the electronic and catalytic behavior of carbon materials [32] could be replaced by an appropriate biomass containing carbon as well as heteroatoms in its intrinsic composition. Such biomass could be used to prepare self-doped carbon materials as good-performing bifunctional oxygen catalysts. Another class of materials with high catalytic activity for energy applications are mesoporous carbon materials loaded with different metals, non-metals and biomaterials, with large surface area, desirable mesostructures, and tunable porosity [30]. Future bifunctional catalyst materials for efficient, low-cost and stable oxygen electrode catalysts could thus be biomass-derived mesoporous carbons and the use of facile synthesis is crucial for their commercial use in various renewable ESC technologies [31,33,34]. For the synthesis of heteroatom-doped carbons, controlled pyrolysis of biomass that is an ideal, widely abundant, cheap, readily available, renewable, sustainable and environment-friendly material rich in carbon and other heteroatoms, including N, could be used [35]. Because of their large surface area, porous carbon materials are typically more active, and the nature of raw materials used in the production of hierarchically porous carbon is critical [36]. Bifunctional oxygen (ORR and OER) catalysts derived from suitable biomass materials will be discussed in the current article. Biomass such as chitin, eggs, tobacco, euonymus japonicas, lysine, and plant residues serve as both carbon and heteroatom (N) precursors, resulting in the self-doping of porous carbons with heteroatoms (N) without the use of any external heteroatom (N) precursors, thus making the synthesis green and environmentally friendly, while NH4Cl was used as an external N-precursor for wood biomass. The ORR and OER mechanisms have been briefly described and the synthesis, morphology, heteroatom-doping and the catalytic efficiency of biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen (ORR and OER) electrodes have been reviewed. It is possibly the first such analysis of bifunctional oxygen catalysts derived from biomass and will be of great benefit to those working in this area. The significance of these materials for applications, future prospects and possible new directions for the material design of biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts with low-overpotential has also been provided for their scalable use in commercial ESC technologies. 2 ORR/OER 2.1 ORR/OER mechanism in conventional materials The performance and efficiency of FCs and MABs depend upon the ORR and OER activity that takes place on the same bifunctional electrode and is important for ESC applications. Thus, for the industrial production of FCs and rechargeable batteries, efficient bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts are required. The deep understanding of the ORR/OER mechanism is however very crucial for developing advanced efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts and hence ORR and OER mechanisms have been discussed for conventional and heteroatom (N)-doped bifunctional catalysts [21]. In aqueous electrolytes, the ORR at the cathode involves four steps: (i) O2 diffusion and adsorption at the surface of electrocatalyst, (ii) transport of electrons from anode to oxygen (adsorbed), (iii) splitting of O = O binding, and (iv) the removal of OH− ions. There are two ORR pathways, an efficient one-step 4e− pathway or a sluggish two-step 2e− pathway for the reduction of oxygen molecules to OH− ions. For direct 4e− pathway, the ORR is O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− (in alkaline medium) and O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O (in acidic medium) [37]. For indirect two-steps 2e− oxygen reduction, the reactions in alkaline solution are O2 + 2e− + H2O → OH− + HO2 −, and H2O + 2e− + HO2 − → 3OH− and in acidic solution are O2 + 2e− + 2H+ → H2O2 and H2O2 + 2e− + 2H+ → 2H2O. The 4e− pathway typically occurs on noble metals, while the 2e− pathway occurs predominantly on carbon materials [38,39]. The ORR is highly irreversible at the molecular level. Oxygen catalysts suffer severe degradation under reversible ORR/OER conditions because the ORR activity is reduced due to noble metals or heteroatom doped carbons’ oxidation during the OER, and the sintering of nanoparticles [15,17]. The inhibition of ORR due to oxidation of the surface makes the bifunctional oxygen catalysts unstable under reversible conditions. It involves multiple steps for electron-transfer based on different oxygen-based species (O*, OH*, OOH*, and O2*, *- representing the active site) on the electrocatalyst surface, the first three of which are intermediate adsorbed species [37,38]. By controlling the surface binding energies of intermediate species, materials with improved activity can be designed. A volcano plot is given in Fig. 2 (A) between ORR activity and oxygen adsorption energy (ΔE o) by calculating the free energies of different intermediates and Pt lies nearest to the top [40,41]. The binding energies of intermediates (OOH*, OH*, and O*) are strongly related, and decoupling is difficult due to the scaling relationship between OOH* and OH* i.e. ΔG OOH = ΔG OH + 3.2 ± 0.2 eV [40]. Even Pt at volcano plot top with best ΔEO has 0.3–0.4 V overpotential, due to non-ideal scaling. Pt does not perform equally well for OER, although it is the best precious metal ORR catalyst with excellent performance. The catalysis pre-requisites in each direction will be quite different due to the large overpotentials required for reactions in two different directions, and metals (Pt) get oxidized at large positive OER potentials and provide a different kind of surface than during ORR [38]. As a result, OER catalysts are typically metal oxides, and Fig. 2(B) shows the OER volcano plot for different metal oxide surfaces based on the adsorption energy difference of O and OH (ΔG O − ΔG OH). OER on the other hand is the opposite of ORR and can result through either usual adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) (Fig. 3 (A)) or lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) (Fig. 3(B)) [21,42,43]. The binding of metal (M) cation with oxygen is weaker at higher covalency, but the reversible formation of lattice oxygen vacancy favors direct O–O bonding. In contrast to AEM, which occurs on a single metal site, LOM typically occurs on two neighboring metal sites (Fig. 3(B)) [44]. The OER mechanism changes from AEM to LOM as metal–oxygen covalency increases [42]. The AEM usually involves metal ions based four proton-electron transfer reactions [46] and a proton is injected into the electrolyte at each step that coalesces with an electron at the cathode. The adsorption strength of main intermediates for an ideal OER catalyst should be moderate, according to the Sabatier principle. The universal volcano-shaped plot of overpotential ɳ OER vs (ΔG O*−ΔG HO*) does not depend on the nature of OER catalyst materials. The role of different ORR and OER active sites has been studied by DFT in acidic medium (pH = 0) and their overpotentials (Z) have been analyzed as per 4e− mechanism using the hydrogen electrode model [40]. The volcano plot shows the weakest interaction of oxygen atom with the substrates for PC, resulting in poor ORR/OER performance, but interaction becomes strong after N-doping and decreases the ORR/OER overpotential. The most efficient ORR active sites are carbon atoms near graphitic-N and at the armchair nanoribbon edge as the best catalytic active site should have the lowest overpotential. The most efficient OER active sites, on the other hand, are the carbon atoms near the graphitic-N, which is 3.34 Å away from the armchair ribbon edge. Thus, according to DFT calculations, carbon atoms near the graphitic-N are the most efficient ORR/OER active sites, and graphitic-N species are more important than pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N [47]. ORR takes place in bifunctional oxygen catalysts through four steps: OOH* formed from adsorbed oxygen (* + O2 + H2O + e− ↔ HOO* + OH−), its reduction to O* (HOO* + e− ↔ OH− + O*) and OH* (H2O + O* + e− ↔ OH− + HO*; e− + HO* ↔ OH−), while OER occurs in the opposite direction and the overall reaction in alkaline medium is O2 + 2H2O + 4e− ↔ 4OH− [38]. The OH* and O2 reduction steps limit the activity of ORR, and steps for the formation of OOH* and O* limit the activity of OER [48,49]. Because the intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*) have different binding energies for OER and ORR catalysts, the best OER catalyst is not necessarily the best ORR catalyst, and vice versa. 2.2 ORR/OER mechanism in N-doped carbons The optimization of heterogeneous oxygen electrocatalysts on the basis of Sabatier principle requires that the binding of intermediate species (OOH*, H*, etc.) at the catalyst surface should neither be too strong nor too weak, and that leads the catalyst to the volcano plot peak [50]. Because the adsorption energies of the intermediates are dependent on the electronic structure of the catalyst surface, different strategies are required to reach the volcano peak, including manipulating the electronic structure of active components. N-doped carbon nanomaterials with improved electrocatalytic activity were followed by doping with other heteroatoms (N, P, B, S, O, etc.), and materials with varying functionalities and structures were discovered to have good ORR and OER electroactivity [51,52]. The electron affinity and electronegativity of the doped heteroatoms is crucial in enhancing catalytic activity. The locations and configurations of heteroatoms have a major impact on the catalytic activity [53] and doping at edge sites is more effective than at the basal plane [53]. The dual and tri-doping of carbons further enhanced the ORR/OER catalytic performance [52]. The simultaneous N and S doping enhanced the charge and spin densities, resulting in higher ORR activity [54] and synergistic coupling between dopants enhanced the activity of each site and improved the performance. The ORR pathway for N-doped carbon materials is given schematically in Fig. 4 . The carbon atoms with Lewis basicity next to pyridinic N are proposed to be ORR active sites in N-doped carbon materials, where oxygen molecules are adsorbed as the first ORR step [55]. Theoretical calculations also revealed that co-doping plays a critical role in OER activity, with lowest overpotential of 0.505 V reported for N, P dual-doped carbon, which is less than single-doped and pristine carbons and even better to IrO2 [56]. Thus, multi-heteroatom doping enriches the active sites and the combination of doping, defects, and edges improve the electrocatalytic activities. In addition, the hierarchical structure is also important in enhancing the catalytic performance by improving accessibility [52]. For different species, the electrocatalytic ORR/OER activity of the N-free topological defect is at the top of volcano plots, followed by doping at edge and in the bulk. The electrocatalytic performance of heteroatoms-doped porous carbons can thus be enhanced by optimizing surface chemistry (doping, edges, defects, functional groups, etc.) as well as hierarchical architecture (higher surface area, micro/meso porosity, etc.) [52]. One major challenge in regulating the intrinsic activity of bifunctional catalysts is different requirements for the ORR/OER active sites [57]. The structure should be tuned to have higher surface area in order to speed up mass diffusion and electron transport, exposing more catalytic active sites. Nanocarbon’s high conductivity and large surface area is good for electrocatalytic activity, while heteroatom-doping creates defects to control the electronic structure of carbon atoms for higher ORR and OER activity [57]. The N-doping modulates the electronic structure of the carbon atoms nearby, which are thought to be active sites, with pyridinic-N and graphitic-N mainly providing catalytic activity [12]. The N and P dual-doped carbon foam showed higher ORR and OER bifunctional activity with P-N bonds contributing to OER and N-dopants to ORR activity. The sp 2 carbon atoms in carbon nanomaterials have a hexagonal lattice, but the experimentally prepared samples have structural defects, and various configurations of carbon atoms in these defects induce different electronic structures. Thus, effective defect modulation has been used to control the bifunctional ORR/OER activity [58] with performance (E 1/2 = 0.77 V, E 10 = 1.67 V) better than catalysts based on precious metals and GO. Recently, hierarchical carbon material containing heteroatom N and defects has been reported as a bifunctional catalyst [59]. Volcano plots were created using the theoretical ORR/OER activity of 13 active sites that includes N-doped sites and defect structures, as calculated by DFT computations (Fig. 5 ). The N-doped defect structure A7, and N-free A6 defect leads to the highest ORR and OER activity, respectively. To make the best use of the active sites, the electrocatalyst’s morphology should expose more active sites to the oxygen feedstocks and electrolyte, resulting in a large surface area and hierarchical pore structure. The high electrical conductivity of carbon materials lowers the electron transfer resistance and in addition the use of conducting substrate facilitate the electron transfer that reduces the resistance at interfaces. Thus, when designing bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, intrinsic activity, quantity, and accessibility of the active sites must be prioritized. The enhancement of ORR/OER activity by co-doping is related to amount of dopant and porous structure, with the former modulating intrinsic catalytic activity and the latter affecting mass transfer [60]. The presence of chlorine in N, S–doped carbon has recently been reported to shift the ORR onset potential, matching Pt/C. The ORR overpotential is reduced by the redistribution of intermediate energies caused by the synergistic effect of N and Cl [61]. A volcano-like relationship has been reported for metal-free carbon materials [62], that is related to the electronegativity and electron affinity of heteroatoms. The ORR performance of N-doped carbons depends upon the reversible redox couples on the surface, by a pH-dependent ORR mechanism [63]. Doping heteroatoms into 1-3D carbon nanomaterials thus improves the ORR activity by modifying the electronic density and state of carbon matrix with heteroatoms that have different electronegativity than carbon [64]. Multi-heteroatom (N, S, P, and B)-doped carbons show performance comparable to Pt/C along with high activity, good durability, and methanol tolerance. Biomass-derived porous carbons are ideal as they mainly contain pyridinic-N and graphitic-N, have a high surface area, porous structures, and large conductivity, all of which are required for active site exposure as well as electron and mass transfer. The architecture of biomass-derived carbons produces good activity (E onset = 0.95 V), long-term stability and high performance for Zn-air batteries. 2.3 Evaluation of ORR/OER performance The ORR and OER are made up of identical steps but in reverse directions. As a consequence, due to the absence of good oxygen electrodes that require the electrocatalyst to be electrochemically stable over a wide potential and pH range, many high energy ESC technologies are not practically viable [45]. A schematic ORR/OER polarization curve (Fig. 6 ) displays different parameters used for evaluating the activity of bifunctional catalysts and are briefly explained. The onset potential (E onset) is the potential at which current deviates from the baseline and is determined from the intersection of the tangents as shown in the CV curve (Fig. 6) after background correction. For ORR, it is obtained by subtracting the polarization curve under N2 from that under O2 and for OER, the onset potential is accurately determined using ring current, as it is the current due to OER only. Since O2 reduction and water oxidation are to overcome the kinetic energy barrier, the ORR onset potential is always lower, but higher for OER, relative to standard redox potential. The current density (j) of the catalyst (current per unit surface area or mass) is related to the rate of conversion or production of O2 and is a critical parameter for the actual performance of the catalyst in devices. Tafel slope (b)-the linear part of overpotential (η) vs current density (j) is expressed by the Tafel equation: η = a + b log (j), where the Tafel slope (b) indicates the reaction pathway and the rate-determining step. A good bifunctional catalyst should have a small b and high j o (at η = 0). The potential difference (△E = Ej 10 − E1/2) between an ORR current density of − 3 mA cm−2 (j 3) and an OER current density of 10 mA cm−2 (j 10) under identical catalyst loading is also related to the overall bifunctional oxygen activity. The sluggish kinetics of the 4e− reversible OER and ORR processes lead to high η, which drastically lowers the energy efficiency, rate capability, and stability. The free energy difference between oxygen (ΔGO ) and hydroxide (ΔGOH ) adsorption (ΔGO – ΔGOH ), on the other hand, maintains the overall OER rate [65,66]. 2.4 Performance of current bifunctional oxygen catalysts Oxygen reactions have sluggish kinetics and large η because of the involvement of four proton-coupled/decoupled electron-transfer and the forming (OER) or breaking (ORR) step of oxygen double bond [21,67]. Due to the occurrence of different steps, intermediates and binding energies of active site with intermediates, the excellent ORR catalysts are not equally good OER catalysts and therefore the formation of multi redox centers for the OER and ORR should be an important strategy. Thus in bifunctional catalysts, multi-active centers are typically present. Composite catalysts based on precious metals currently exhibit the best OER and ORR activity, with E 1/2 greater than 0.8 V, and for OER, j 10 less than 1.6 V, with the exception of Pt. The integration of the best ORR catalysts based on noble metals with the most active OER materials (Pt-Ir composites) shows △E less than 0.7 V [68]. Transition metal oxides are potential candidates for the design of bifunctional catalysts because they are economical and abundant. Single metal-oxides often show E 1/2 in the 0.53–0.81 V range for ORR and the j 10 over 1.7 V for OER, resulting in △E greater than 1.0 V, while only α-MnO2 that is rich in oxygen defects shows a lower △E of 0.91 V [69], but this is not good due to the large η. Perovskites (ABO3) show j 10 at 1.6–1.7 V potential for OER [70] that is higher than of single-metal-oxides, but still lower ORR activity with E 1/2 less than 0.7 V and the perovskites are thus less efficient bifunctional catalysts due to large η (△E ~ 0.9–1.1 V). Spinels (AB2O4) show higher bifunctional performance with △E in the 0.8–1.1 V range. Both reactions are not buffered by these materials because of the different OER and ORR mechanisms. The tuning of composition and structure of composites results in significantly higher bifunctional performance [68,71,72] with E1/2 for ORR greater than 0.8 V, and j 10 less than 1.6 V for OER, resulting in △E in the 0.66–1.16 V range, with lowest △E (0.66 V) for NiO/CoO [71]. The OER/ORR active sites in carbon could be created by defect engineering by modifying carbons with large surface area and higher conductivity from 1-3D porous structures and it provides vast scope for developing highly active bifunctional catalysts [73]. The defects introduced by heteroatom-doping result in better performance compared to the inherent carbon and oxygen defects. N-doped carbons generally exhibit the best bifunctional activity with △E in the 0.8–1.0 V range [29,74]. Dual-heteroatoms co-doping leads to improved activity with △E < 0.8 V [75–77], with S-modulated holey C2N aerogels showing minimum (0.65 V) △E [76]. By combining the transition metal oxides that have high activity with carbon materials, the performance of bifunctional oxygen catalysts could be further enhanced, resulting in strong interaction among elements to create multi-active centers and a high conducting pathway for electron transfer [78,79]. These centers are OER/ORR active, and the multi-element composites not only have a strong interaction that results in the best synergistic effect, but they also have the most active center and the lowest η for both oxygen reactions. Because of their high ORR and OER activity, these composites are one of the best-performing bifunctional catalysts, with △E less than 0.8 V. However as discussed above, despite the good performance of traditional bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, their higher cost, insufficient availability and complex synthesis are not commercially viable for their scalable production for use in ESC devices. This prompted the use of earth-abundant freely available biomass materials containing carbon and different heteroatoms in their intrinsic composition to synthesize heteroatom-doped porous carbons as bifunctional oxygen catalysts with higher ORR and OER catalytic activity simultaneously. In the following sections, N self-doped porous carbons derived from biomass that contain N in their intrinsic composition have been discussed as bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts: 3 Biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts 3.1 Chitin The synthesis of heteroatom-doped carbon materials directly from natural resources is good for potential use as electrocatalysts, but usually requires an extra annealing step under NH3 atmosphere to enhance the N content [80]. The direct conversion of biomass into a highly active bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst is reported only in limited studies. In this respect, chitin, an abundant N-containing natural biopolymer is generally derived from shrimp, crab, crayfish and krill shells after consuming them as food. Being renewable, biodegradable, non-toxic and also having lower density, chemically stable and bio-active, chitin is widely used in different fields [9]. For use as electrodes in supercapacitors, chitin can be suitably transformed into mesoporous N-doped carbons [81]. Recently, chitin-based N-doped carbon was prepared as bifunctional catalyst and ZnCl2 activation enhanced its activity [31]. Chitin-derived activated carbon, along with excellent OER activity, exhibited high ORR activity and improved stability than Pt/C. The chitin-derived carbon sheet (CS) was synthesized by the carbonization of hydrothermal product of chitin and activated carbon sheet (ACS) was prepared by activating CS with ZnCl2 [82] and excess ZnCl2 was leached out using HCl, followed by extensive washing with water. The SEM micrographs of the surface show sheet morphology containing different porous structures for CS, but ACS shows more and bigger cracks than the CS. The surface morphology of chitin-based (Fig. 7 (A)) and activated (Fig. 7(B)) carbon has sheet morphology containing different porous structures and chemical activation increases the crack size and is reflected in surface area increase from 100 to 300 cm2 g−1. [31]. After activation, the surface area (100.0 m2 g−1) and total pore volume (0.06 cm3 g−1) of CS increased significantly to 300.7 m2 g−1 and 0.31 cm3 g−1, respectively, but both had 3.81 nm pore diameters with a wider pore-size distribution for ACS. The enhanced porosity of ACS is because of ZnCl2 activation by a redox reaction, and it is an efficient process for producing AC with a large surface area and micropore distribution from natural materials [82]. As a result, activation is critical in the synthesis of high surface area and wide micropore carbon materials with good electrochemical performance. XPS surface functionality analysis reveals that C, N, and O are present in ACS, with a higher O and N content than in CS. The deconvoluted XPS N 1 s spectrum reveals pyridinic-, pyrrolic- and graphitic-N peaks, and pyridinic-N bonds to two C atoms at the edge of a carbon plane and a carbon vacancy and can adsorb O2 as well as its intermediates in ORR. Pyridinic-N, on the other hand, enhances the ORR electrocatalytic activity by increasing its electron-donating property. As a result, ACS with a high N content, a higher pyridinic-N proportion, and a porous structure have more active oxygen reduction sites, leading to enhanced ORR activity. Both CS and ACS showed cathodic peaks for oxygen reduction in O2 saturated electrolyte, and the positive peak potential (–0.24 V vs. SCE) of ACS is because of N-doping. Furthermore, increased surface area due to ZnCl2 activation resulted in more surface functional groups and active sites on carbon material, which improved electrocatalytic activity of ACS. The cathodic current shown by ACS is greater than the cathodic current shown by CS. The ORR mechanism was studied by rotating disk electrode (RDE) and the voltammograms are shown in Fig. 7(D). An increase in limited current density at higher rotation speeds indicates smaller diffusion distance. The ACS has an onset potential (–0.15 V vs. SCE) very close to Pt (–0.13 V vs. SCE), but is sufficiently higher than many other carbon catalysts. The diffusion limiting current plateau, however is quite similar to metal-free ORR carbon catalysts. The electron transfer number (n = 3.87–3.99) of ACS at –0.5 to –0.8 V potential is near Pt/C indicating a 4e− efficient ORR process. A positive shift observed in the onset potential and an increase in the ORR reduction current on ACS electrode contribute to excellent catalytic activity, and ZnCl2 activation helps to reduce the ORR overpotential. The effect of metal impurities on the ORR activity of ACS could also be studied by preparing totally metal-free electrodes from chitin. In addition to excellent ORR activity, ACS also showed higher OER activity, proving that it is a good bifunctional catalyst. The onset of OER electrocatalytic activity was measured by LSV in the –0.2 to 1.0 V range, covering the water oxidation (Fig. 7E), and showed catalytic currents of –20.7, –3.9, and –12.4 mA cm−2 for ACS, CS, and Pt/C, respectively, at ~ 1.06, 1.64, and 1.62 V vs. RHE and OER current density. The OER activity of ACS is excellent and the potential required to oxidize water at 10 mA cm−2 current density is used to calculate OER activity, and the value (1.64 ± 0.02 V vs. RHE) for ACS is very close to 1.60 ± 0.01 V vs. RHE for IrO2/C and N-doped graphene/CNT hybrids [84,85]. As a result, chemical activation of ACS leads to increased OER activity. The ACS has much lower Tafel slope (90 mV dec−1) than the CS (116 mV dec−1) and Pt/C (104 mV dec−1) which supports its higher OER performance. Therefore, N-doped metal-free carbons are OER active, and N-species act as OER active centers, with higher pyridinic- and quaternary-N levels increasing OER activity [85]. The main reasons for ACS’s excellent OER activity are its higher N-content (4.99%) and large surface area (300.7 m2 g−1) compared to 3.69% and 106.4 m2 g−1 for CS, and especially the high fraction of pyridinic-N (3.2%). As a result of this simple and low-cost method, the chitin-derived ACS is suitable for potential applications in ESC devices. The presence of a high surface area, N-content, and porous structure results in more active sites, which are desirable for ORR, as well as good durability and fuel crossover resistance in alkaline electrolytes. ACS also showed higher OER activity. As a result, these metal-free chitin-derived catalysts with efficient electron pathways are suitable as efficient bifunctional oxygen (ORR and OER) catalysts. In another study, chitin was used as an ideal C and N precursor to prepare N-doped carbon catalysts [83,86] via a simple green route that involved dissolving chitin in an alkali/urea aqueous solution at a lower temperature using freezing-thawing cycles [87]. Chitin-based N-doped carbons were prepared by tailoring the microstructure and porosity of chitin hydrogels during synthesis, resulting in ideal porosity, required morphology and microstructure suitable for use as high-performance bifunctional oxygen catalysts [87]. Low cost, environmentally friendly, and stable graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with a high N content, sp 2 bonding structure, numerous N dopants, and defects is more suitable for use in energy devices than other N-doped carbons. The composites of ultrathin g-C3N4 (good ORR catalyst) and graphene (durable and efficient OER catalyst) demonstrate suitability of g-C3N4 in bifunctional oxygen catalysts [84,88]. The low catalytic activity of g-C3N4 due to its low electrical conductivity could be improved by using a composite of chitin-based N-doped carbon with g-C3N4, which could enhance conductivity and thus catalytic performance. As a result, chitin-derived N-doped carbon composites (C-Chitin/g-C3N4) were prepared by a facile method that involves the dissolution and carbonization of biomass chitin [84]. Samples containing 0, 0.25, 1, and 4 wt% g-C3N4 were labeled as C-Chitin and C-Chitin/g- C3N4-1, 2, and 3, respectively. C-Chitin’s morphology and microstructure reveal distinct honeycomb-like 3D networks with curved interconnected ultrathin nanosheets that are nearly transparent. The C-Chitin/g-C3N4 composites also have honeycomb-like architectures that slowly changes into a loofa sponge-like 3D network as the g-C3N4 concentration increases. The TEM image of composites (Fig. 7(C)) confirms that the interconnected network architecture is made up of ultrathin flexible nanosheets with visible wrinkles and corrugations. The carbonization of chitin results in the uniform presence of a large number of mesopores (2–5 nm) on the sheets, indicating the mesoporous nature of composites [83]. The curved C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 composite nanosheets form an interconnected network by randomly connecting with adjoining sheets, creating numerous voids and active sites. The loofa sponge-like architecture is ideal for ORR and OER because it improves electrolyte-catalyst contacts, facilitate efficient mass and charge transport, and provides abundant catalytically active sites. XRD and FTIR confirmed the presence of N-doped carbon and g-C3N4 in composites, as well as the presence of all characteristic peaks of components. Higher I D/I G intensity ratio in Raman spectra indicates a disordered structure and the presence of more defects with the addition of g-C3N4. The surface area of C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 composites (87.19 m2 g−1) confirms the presence of mesoporous features, and the pore size distribution with many sharp peaks in the 2–5 nm pore size range is due to the presence of mesoporous channels. The broad peak for ORR and OER in the 50–200 nm range is due to macropores, and the large surface area of composites with mesoporous structures is important because it provides numerous catalytic active sites and also facilitates reactant species transport [89,90]. C-Chitin contains C, N, and O [88], and due to the presence of g-C3N4, the C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 composite had a higher N content (13.19 at%) than C-Chitin (5.75 at%). The deconvolution of the high-resolution N1s spectrum (Fig. 7(F)) reveals four peaks at different binding energies due to pyridinic-, pyrrolic-, graphitic-, and oxidized-N. Pyridinic-N is the strongest peak in the C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 composite, implying that the addition of g-C3N4 contributes more pyridinic-N to composites that play a significant role in enhancing O2 reduction [51] and also serve as an OER active site. Thus, higher pyridinic-N fractions in composites contribute to increased ORR and OER intrinsic bifunctional activity. In oxygen-saturated electrolyte, all composites show a clear cathodic peak, and composites with higher g-C3N4 content show more positive peak potential, indicating improved ORR performance and a higher current density (4.54 mA cm−2 at 0.2 V) close to Pt/C. Thus, g-C3N4 helps to improve catalyst performance while also providing excellent selectivity and methanol tolerance, and the measured transferred electron number of 3.9 indicates an efficient 4e− efficient ORR pathway. At higher g-C3N4 content, the electrocatalytic activity of C-Chitin composites with g-C3N4 exhibits lower onset potential and higher OER current density than composites with lower g-C3N4 content (Fig. 7(G)). C-Chitin and its composites exhibit significantly higher OER catalytic activity than g-C3N4 and Pt/C, making them suitable for use as bifunctional catalysts. Chitin-based catalysts have higher activity due to their distinct microstructure and appropriate composition. The sponge-like 3D network made of ultrathin nanosheets has the potential to improve catalyst-electrolyte contacts, assist active species diffusion, accelerate surface reactions, and provide efficient pathways for mass and charge transport. The large surface area exposes many active sites to O2 during ORR, and the mesoporous structures allow for efficient reactant transport [90]. N-doping of C-Chitin improves catalytic activity by modulating electronic properties and providing many active sites [90], whereas the addition of g-C3N4 in composites improves catalytic activity due to the high N-content, and electronic structure with numerous N-species and defects [87]. This contributes to the overall higher bifunctional oxygen activity of chitin and g-C3N4 composites. The overall activity of bifunctional oxygen electrode is generally measured using ΔE = E j=10 − E 1/2, and the smaller the ΔE, the closer it is to an ideal reversible oxygen electrode [91]. The C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 has a much lower ΔE (0.90 V) (Fig. 7(H)), and ΔE analysis shows that all catalysts have ΔE lower than Pt/C (inset), confirming the superior performance of chitin-derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts. Stability is also important for practical applications of composites as a bifunctional catalyst, and high ORR stability was observed with 89.9% retention of the initial current after 50000 s, compared to 45% loss for Pt/C in alkaline environment. Furthermore, when compared to Pt/C, these composites exhibit higher ORR selectively and better methanol tolerance. The OER stability also shows 13.2% anodic current attenuation within 50000 s, compared to 29.8% for Pt/C, and the LSV curves confirm the composites’ high stability for OER. Composites of C-Chitin/g-C3N4-2 with high stability and excellent catalytic activity could be potential bifunctional oxygen catalysts for energy applications. The simple synthesis of chitin-derived N self-doped carbons from abundant low-cost biomass is scalable and appears promising as an efficient bifunctional oxygen catalyst. 3.2 Eggs Eggs with a high concentration of proteins, cholesterols, and lecithins serve as the sole precursor of C and heteroatoms (N, P, O, and Fe) for intrinsic and homogeneous self-doping. To achieve high catalytic activity, self-doping with heteroatoms is preferred avoiding the use of external precursors. To synthesize egg carbon microspheres (egg-CMS) homogeneously doped with N, P, and Fe from eggs, an ecofriendly and simple spray-drying of egg-based sol–gels including TEOS and without any external doping precursor was reported [22]. In addition, egg-derived carbon (egg-C) without TEOS was prepared under identical conditions for comparison. The heteroatoms (N, P, and Fe) found in eggs are uniformly distributed in the carbon network. The SEM image of egg-CMS (Fig. 8 (A)) shows a microsphere morphology with a diameter of approximately 4.5 μm, whereas the TEM image (Fig. 8(B)) shows a high graphitization degree, which is related to the presence of transition metal nanoparticles and high temperature annealing. The samples retained the same morphology even after etching or removing carbon by calcination, indicating uniform mixing of the two components. The surface of the egg-CMS is covered with tiny nanoparticles and has a uniform structure with a high degree of graphitization. The etching of the silica contact in these egg-CMS samples resulted in a large surface area (970 m2 g−1), pore volume (0.5 cm3 g−1), and mesopore size in the 2–4 nm range. The egg-C, on the other hand, is non-spherical and has a much lower surface area (3 m2 g−1), highlighting the importance of silica in the formation of mesopores and microsphere structures. The XPS of egg-CMS shows a uniform distribution of C (69.1%), O (20.1%), N (8.2%), P (2.41%), and Fe (0.22%) (Fig. 8(C)). The high sp 2-carbon content increases conductivity of carbon while also improving the electrochemical activity of both OER and ORR [92]. The greater proportion of dominant and highly electroactive pyridinic- and graphitic-N (41.9 and 35.7%) species endows these materials with higher OER and ORR activity. The peaks of P 2p, P − C (68.5%) and P − O (31.5%), are due to phosphorus bonding [93] and increase the electrocatalytic ORR activity. The presence of Fe3+ detected by XPS also contributes to the OER. The oxygen reduction peak in KOH is observed in the CV curves, and the reduction potential for egg-CMS at 0.89 V is slightly negative of Pt/C (0.96 V), indicating excellent ORR activity. The ORR LSV plots (Fig. 8(D)) show a limiting current density of 4.36 mA cm−2, indicating higher ORR catalytic activity. The onset (0.84 V) and a half-wave (0.69 V) potential vs RHE for egg-CMS indicate the role of higher surface area and heteroatoms co-doping. Methanol tolerance and durability of the egg-CMS is much better than commercial Pt/C. The durability, measured using chronoamperometry at 0.3 V for 20 h continuously, revealed that the egg-CMS has a higher (92%) current retention than Pt/C (76%), confirming its superior durability. The OER activity of egg-CMS (Fig. 8(E)) has a high current density of 74.6 mA cm−2 at 1.6 V vs RHE and a low OER onset potential of 1.51 V vs RHE. The low Tafel slope of egg-CMS (59 mV dec−1) confirms its superior electrochemical OER performance. OER stability as measured by chronoamperometric method revealed that egg-CMS retained 95% of its current, indicating its high durability in OER. The highly porous nature of the egg-CMS and low impedance indicate that the OER has higher conductivity. A simple and low-cost approach could therefore be used to synthesize eggs-based heteroatom self-doped carbon microspheres (egg-CMS) and the use of sol–gel chemistry results in high surface area, large pore volume, and self-heteroatom doping. The egg-CMS exhibits higher bifunctional (ORR and OER) activity, making it suitable for air electrodes in Zn-air batteries. A battery assembled using carbon paper coated with egg-CMS as the cathode and Zn foil as the anode (Fig. 8(F)) had an open circuit potential of 1.3 V, suggesting good catalytic activity. During a 60 h discharge, the cell showed an output potential of over 1.21 V at 5.5 mA cm−2. Even after 30 cycles, the battery maintained the output voltage at 1 V, retaining 78% of the voltage. The egg-derived self-doped carbon therefore represents a novel strategy for producing environmentally friendly and sustainable bifunctional catalysts for ESC technologies. 3.3 Tobacco To better understand the role of different N species in the bifunctional oxygen catalysts (ORR and OER) used in RFCs and MABs, nicotine-containing tobacco was used as a low-cost raw material to synthesize N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (N-OMC) [94,95]. In addition, N-OMC1 was prepared using tobacco and dicyandiamide, while by physically mixing dicyandiamide and extract of pure tobacco, N-OMC2 was prepared. SEM (Fig. 9 (A)) and TEM images (Fig. 9(B)) of tobacco-based N-OMC2 samples containing dicyandiamide show the presence of ordered graphitic carbon with porous surface containing 3.85% N, smaller surface area (520.8 m2 g−1) and larger mesopopre size (14.2 nm), which is due to the direct mixing of tobacco extract and dicyandiamide [95]. The morphology of samples prepared using phenol show ordered graphitic carbon, while those prepared from tobacco extract also display similar morphology with porous surface. All tobacco-based samples are mesoporus, with a surface area of 1227.2 m2 g−1 for N-OMC1 that is much higher than 781.5 m2 g−1 for N-OMC, and an average mesopore size of 12.1 nm for N-OMC1 that is less than 14.0 nm for N-OMC. The surface area of N-OMC2 (520.8 m2 g−1) is much lower than N-OMC and N-OMC1, but a larger mesopore size (14.2 nm) than N-OMC and N-OMC1, implying that direct mixing results in larger pore size but a lower surface area. The N-OMC had an N-content of 1.58 wt%, indicating that tobacco N-components are good precursors for N-doping. In accordance with XPS results, the N-content in N-OMC1 (4.06 wt%) and N-OMC2 (3.85 wt%) is higher than N-OMC. In the XPS N1s deconvoluted spectrum, pyridine-, pyrrole- and graphite-N species are observed [96–84]. N-OMC and N-OMC1 have higher graphitic-N (64.3 and 68.2 at%) and lower pyrrolic-N (12.5 and 7.9 at%) and pyridinic-N (23.2 and 23.9 at%), than for N-OMC2. The presence of more pyrrolic-N (49.6 at%), pyridinic-N (40.2 at%) and lower graphitic-N (10.2 at%), in N-OMC2 compared to N-OMC and N-OMC1, suggests that the mixing mode of dicyandiamide alters the distribution of N-species. At 80 °C, it transforms to NH3, affecting the structure of the N precursor for N-OMC1 (NH3) more than dicyandiamide for N-OMC2, resulting in N species different distributions in N-OMC1 and N-OMC2. The CV curves in alkaline medium show ORR peak current density of 3.13 mA cm−2 at ~ − 0.30 V in N-OMC, much higher than 2.25 mA cm−2 at − 0.34 V for OMC, indicating that natural N in tobacco effectively improves the ORR activity, as N-OMC with lower surface area (781.5 m2 g−1) shows higher ORR activity than OMC having comparatively higher surface area (1255.1 m2 g−1). However, the peak current density of N-OMC is much lower than N-OMC1 (3.44 mA cm−2) and N-OMC2 (3.24 mA cm−2). LSV measurements (Fig. 9(C)) show more positive onset potential (−0.11 V) for N-OMC than pure OMC (−0.18 V). In the − 0.14 V to − 1.0 V range, the N-doped OMCs also show higher diffusion current densities than un-doped OMCs, leading to an improvement in the ORR performance of OMCs. The onset potential (+0.06 V) of N-OMC2 is even higher (−0.01 V) than Pt/C, along with a diffusion current density that is also higher than Pt/C, showing that N-OMC2 is the best ORR catalyst among OMCs in alkaline medium. The CV and LSV curves (Fig. 9(D)) show that N-doped OMC exhibit much high ORR activity compared to un-doped OMC, and N-OMC2 has the best ORR performance in acidic medium compared to other samples. N-OMC2 also show n = 3.68 and 3.52 in alkaline and acidic medium, respectively that is much higher than for other samples, suggesting efficient 4-electron reduction. N-OMC2 has higher pyrrolic- and pyridinic-N and smaller graphitic-N proportion and low surface area, whereas N-OMC1 has high surface area. For N-OMC2, the above results show that pyridinic- and pyrrolic-N contribute more than graphitic-N to improve ORR activity. The durability studies of N-OMC2 showed a loss of 2.9% and 5.8% of the initial peak current density in alkaline and acidic medium, respectively after 6000 cycles that is quite low compared to 16.2 and 31.9% loss for Pt/C, indicating its much higher stability. In fact, all the N-doped OMCs and commercial Ir/C catalysts exhibited much higher OER activity. N-OMC2 also showed onset potential of + 0.05 V and current density of 10 mA cm−2 at + 0.76 V for OER in alkaline medium (Fig. 9E), that is much higher than other samples, along with the best OER activity in acidic medium (Fig. 9F). In comparison to graphitic-N, the best ORR/OER performance displayed by N-OMC2 suggests an improvement of OER activity, predominately by pyrrolic- and pyridinic-N, similar to ORR. Therefore, N-OMC1 showed high surface area and larger graphitic-N, whereas N-OMC2 contains more pyrrolic- and pyridinic-N and therefore displayed much higher ORR and OER activity than N-OMC1 containing more graphitic-N. It indicates that the presence of more pyrrolic- and pyridinic-N improves the ORR/OER activity of N-doped carbons that is desirable for future RFCs and rechargeable MABs. 3.4 Euonymus japonicus leaves In order to obtain hierarchical carbons by avoiding complex processing or activation, the selection of raw materials is very important and for that euonymus japonicas leaves could be an appropriate biomass. For its use as a good raw material for synthesizing N-doped hierarchical PCNs with good ORR/OER catalytic activity, the perfect micro-layered structure of euonymus japonicas leaves is suitable. N-doped PCNs (NPCNs) as biomass-derived metal-free bifunctional oxygen catalysts have been synthesized by a low-cost, scalable and efficient approach using euonymus japonicus leaves as C and N precursor [97]. Schematic details of the synthesis method are given in Fig. 10 (A) and the prepared samples were labelled as NPCNS-T, at different carbonization temperatures (T= 700, 800, 900, and 1000 °C). TEM (Fig. 10(B)) and SEM (Fig. 10(C)) images of NPCNS-900 show irregular nanosheets with a porous sponge structure having a high surface area. The perfect layered microstructure of euonymus japonicas leaves indicates that it is an appropriate biomass for synthesizing heteroatom self-doped hierarchical (micro- and meso-) porous carbon nanosheets as bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts [97]. The biomass-derived carbon nanosheets have an irregular shape with a porous sponge structure and a large surface area [97]. The dominant presence of graphitic carbon is observed in XRD results, and the D and G bands in Raman spectrum are due to structural defects or heteroatom substitution and graphitic carbon, respectively, and the I D/I G ratio indicates that structural alignment is affected by the carbonization temperature. The micro- and mesopore formation was studied by TGA under argon atmosphere and showed three main weight loss steps: (i) first small weight loss by 7.79% below 200.0 °C due to the loss of residual H2O, (ii) second significant weight loss by 69.77% at 200.0–666.8 °C because of the dissociation of macromolecules present in leaves and (iii) the third weight loss by 1.87% at 666.8–1000 °C, indicating the completion of carbonization process. The pyrolysis gases evolved during carbonization helped in the porous structure evolvement at higher temperatures. The surface areas of 750.45, 882.67, 842.33, and 683.26 m2 g−1 at 700, 800, 900, and 1000 °C, respectively, follow a volcanic type curve with increasing carbonization temperature and is due to the combined effect of the release of pyrolysis gases and collapsing of pores during pyrolysis [98–86]. The pore volume (0.633 cm3 g−1), three pore size distributions (<2 nm, 2–5 nm, and 10–50 nm), and the incorporation of micropores into mesopores result in a hierarchical porous structure. The presence of C, N, and O and the absence of any metal in NPCNS-900 is confirmed from XPS results. The C1s XPS spectrum shows different peaks at 284.5 (C = C), 285.1 (C − C), 285.7 (C − N), 286.6 (C = O), and 289.8 eV (C − O), confirming N-doping. Pyridinic-, pyrrolic-, and graphitic-N are the three N-species detected in the deconvoluted N 1 s spectrum. The NPCNS-900 contains maximum proportion of graphitic-N (1.83%) and pyridinic-N (0.61%), whereas the highest content of pyrrolic-N (0.77%) is present in NPCNS-700 (Fig. 10(D)). Among the various N-species, pyridinic- and graphitic-N have previously been identified as key ORR active sites, and a good ORR catalyst should bind oxygen ~ 0.2 eV weakly than Pt [99]. DFT results also show that pyridinic-N with medium O and OH adsorption energies plays a major role in improving the ORR performance of NPCNS-900. The presence of a peak in O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH indicates a cathodic process on this electrode, according to CV studies. The onset potential (0.98 V) of NPCNS-900 is higher than that of Pt/C (0.95 V) and other similar materials. The best ORR performance of the sample carbonized at 900 °C is reinforced by the limiting current density of 3.37 mA cm−2 at 0.4 V. Furthermore, it exhibits good ORR performance in the acid electrolyte via an efficient 4e− pathway, similar to commercial Pt/C as well as better methanol crossover resistance. The excellent performance is ascribed to both the hierarchical porous structure and the higher proportion of active N sites. In addition to having a higher ORR performance, these samples also have a higher current density and an earlier onset potential than Pt/C, suggesting a higher OER catalytic activity. The start of OER on NPCNS-900 at 1.57 V vs. RHE is the lowest and much lower than Pt/C (>1.7 V), making it an excellent OER catalyst. It has the lowest Tafel slope of 191 mV dec−1 (Fig. 10E), which is consistent with other metal-free carbon-based OER catalysts [23,74] and with LSV results indicating more efficient oxygen evolution kinetics, resulting in new bifunctional oxygen evolution electrodes. NPCNS-900 is durable and loses only 16.4% current density for OER and maintains its original morphology after long-term use. The OER performance close to transition metal based catalysts is appropriate for low cost biomass-based carbon catalysts along with good ORR performance, confirming that NPCNS-900 is a potential bifunctional oxygen (ORR and OER) electrocatalyst. The morphology of carbon materials derived from Euonymus radicans (Fig. 10(F)) and Buxus microphylla (Fig. 10(G)) under same synthetic conditions as for NPCNS-900 also show nanosheets with irregular shape and porous sponge structure and excellent bifunctional ORR/OER activity, comparable to NPCNS-900. 3.5 L-lysine biomass Besides heteroatom-doping, the structural design is also crucial for enhancing ORR/OER activity as both reactions occur at the interface/surface of catalysts. Thus, during the ORR/OER, the high surface area and pores/channels on the walls of hollow structures could provide smooth transfer of O2 and electrolytes and shorten the diffusion path of ions/electrons [100]. Hollow catalysts are currently synthesized using templates and toxic chemicals are then used to remove them, but it is not environmentally friendly, so a simple and sustainable strategy is required for synthesizing hollow structured carbons. In this context, L-lysine, a natural renewable biomass source that is produced in bulk (1.2 × 109 kg year−1) by fermentation of various sugars has been used as a carbon precursor to prepare N-doped carbon hollow cubes (CHCs) with a NaCl template via an eco-friendly and simple method [101]. For the first time, carbon hollow structures are synthesized from lysine via a salt template method and the template (NaCl) used is simply removed by water, without affecting structures and active sites. Self-doping of N from biomass precursor is homogeneously distributed and the resulting N-doped carbon shows excellent bifunctional oxygen (ORR and OER) catalytic activity. The solution of NaCl in L-lysine monohydrochloride (C6H15O2N2Cl) was dried at 80 °C and the NaCl crystals were precipitated, resulting in C6H15O2N2Cl@NaCl. The biomass transformed into N-doped carbon after carbonization at 1000 °C and was labelled NC@NaCl. By washing with DI water, NaCl crystals were then removed and light and soft N-doped CHCs (NCHCs) were obtained. For comparison, N-doped carbon (NC) was synthesized in the absence of NaCl by pyrolysis of C6H15O2N2Cl. The schematic details of the synthesis process are given in Fig. 11 (A). The morphology of N-doped carbon as observed from the SEM (Fig. 11(B)) and TEM (Fig. 11(C)) images show hollow cube structure with 1–2 μm size and 10 nm shell thickness, while only flakes are observed in carbon directly carbonized from biomass without any NaCl. HRTEM images (Fig. 11(D)) show improved graphite structure with the absence of metal-based oxide or carbide, as has been observed from SAED (inset of Fig. 11(D)). The elemental mapping reveals the presence of C, N, and O, and N is distributed homogenously in the hollow carbon cubes [101]. The NCHCs have both micro- and meso-pores centered at 1.19 and 8.78 nm respectively, and with the addition of NaCl, the surface area of NC (2.1 m2 g−1) increased to 347 m2 g−1 which is the optimum value for use as an ORR electrocatalyst. The lower intensity ratio (ID /IG ) in NCHC is due to its higher degree of graphitization than NC, and the higher graphitization is because of the promoting effect of molten salt (NaCl) at higher temperature [102]. The chemical state and composition at the surface of catalysts, analysed by XPS, confirm the presence of C, N, and O along with N-content 4.0 in NCHC and 5.8% in NC. The deconvoluted N 1 s spectrum for NC and NCHCs shows the presence of pyridinic-, pyrrolic- and graphitic-N with the graphitic-N proportion increasing from 57% (NC) to 76% (NCHC) due to the high degree of graphitization. Different N-species create a different environment (chemical and electronic) for adjoining carbon atoms (Fig. 11E), resulting in different electrocatalytic activities. Graphitic- and pyridinic-N are two highly active (ORR and OER) catalytic centers adjoining the dopant in the N-doped structure [62], so NCHCs with higher graphitic- and pyridinic-N content have higher catalytic activity. The presence of an oxygen reduction peak in O2-saturated KOH solution is observed in CV curves, with a larger area under NCHCs than NC. A quasi 4e− pathway is observed for electro-reduction of O2 with n = 3.7 ± 0.1 and a low (15%) peroxide content. At low overpotentials, NCHCs have a higher Tafel slope (76 mV dec−1) than Pt/C (62 mV dec−1) indicating greater catalytic activity. Because of the increased flow rate of oxygen, LSVs of NCHCs show an increasing current with increasing rotating speed (400–2500 rpm). The electron transfer number on NCHCs at different potentials is close to 4 during ORR, indicating that ORR proceeds via a quasi-4e− pathway that is consistent with RRDE results, confirming NCHCs’s high ORR activity. Due to the hollow structure, N-doping into carbon results in high electron conductivity in NCHC than NC along with a shorter ion and electron diffusion path. The excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity of NCHCs is greatly aided by their low charge transfer resistance. NCHCs show a loss of 1 mV only in half wave potential, compared to 17 mV for Pt/C, and also show higher methanol tolerance than Pt/C, suggesting high stability and methanol crossover resistance of NCHCs. The OER activity of NCHCs, NC and RuO2/C (20 wt%) was tested with LSV in N2 -saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm and the NCHCs have an onset potential of 1.52 V, which is similar to RuO2/C. The much lower (90 mV dec−1) Tafel slope of NCHCs than for NC (254 mV dec−1) and RuO2/C (152 mV dec−1) suggests an excellent ORR catalytic activity. The durability of the OER catalysts shows a 54.3% decrease for RuO2/C, compared to a 9% decrease in the OER current for NCHCs after 12 hours of continuous operation at 1.6 V. The higher durability of NCHCs is due to the high degree of graphitization and N-doping, and the lower charge transfer resistance suggests that the hollow cube structure and higher N-doping playa beneficial role in OER. The potential difference between the ORR and the OER was used to evaluate the overall bifunctional oxygen electrode activity. NCHCs have a potential difference of 0.93 V (Fig. 11(F)), comparable to spinel oxide catalysts. The ORR/OER activities of NCHC are comparable and is even higher than for some reported N-doped carbons, implying that NCHCs are promising bifunctional oxygen catalysts. Several factors influence a catalyst’s ORR/OER activity: (i) lower ID/IG for NCHCs means lower structural defects than NC, (ii) large surface area of NCHCs (347 m2 g−1) than NC (2.1 m2 g−1) enables more active sites exposed and high ORR/OER activity in NCHCs than in NC, (iii) total pyridinic- and graphitic-N content are close for HCNC and NC, (iv) large surface area exposes the majority of the pyridinic- and graphitic -N in HCNCs, which participates in the ORR, and (v) the low charge transfer resistance of NCHCs induced by the hollow cubic structure imparts high bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic activity of NCHCs. A scalable, ecofriendly and sustainable strategy for synthesizing N-doped CHCs with thin shells, large surface area and homogeneous N-doping from lysine biomass has been proposed using a NaCl template. These special features enable NCHCs to exhibit efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic activity in alkaline medium with performance matching commercial catalysts (Pt/C and RuO2). This environment-friendly, economical and sustainable strategy is suitable for metal-free bifunctional catalysts for ESC technologies. 3.6 Plant residue The annual generation of nearly 100 billion metric tons of agricultural biomass residues has serious ecological consequences, including a burden on waste management, greenhouse gas emissions, and polluted water. In addition, many biomasses have distinct structures and contain C, N, and O elements required for catalysis, and are thus being studied [103]. Converting low-cost biomass into technological materials is thus critical, and a green strategy for the scalable preparation of bifunctional catalysts from Acori Tatarinowii Rhizoma (ATR) biomass waste was recently reported [104]. Impurities were first removed from ATR by ultrasonically washing it with pure water to produce ATR residue (ATRR), which was then devolatilized. Before being freeze-dried and pyrolyzed under Ar at 850 °C, the pre-carbonized material was sonicated and uniformly mixed with ammonia chloride (NH4Cl) solution, and samples were prepared with NH4Cl to ATRR ratios of 0 (BRC850) and 0.5 (BRCA850). Following sonication, all samples were given a hydrothermal treatment to enhance the surface area. After freeze-drying, the samples were pyrolyzed again at 850 °C under Ar and labeled as BRCAC8502 [105]. The preparation method is depicted schematically in Fig. 12 (A). During the pyrolysis of pre-carbonized ATRR, NH4Cl is added to improve porous structure and N-doping, while hydrothermal treatment and second pyrolysis enhances the surface area and graphitization. BRCAC8502 maintains the 3D tubular array structure of ATRR (Fig. 12(B)), and high magnification images (Fig. 12(C)) show the presence of macropores and mesopores. HRTEM images (Fig. 12(D)) show the formation of a worm-like structure with abundant microporous structure, which results in electrocatalytic site carbon defects [105]. The morphology and microstructure of ATRR reveal that the 3D tubular structure is retained and the NH4Cl treatment adds numerous nanopores to the surface. As a result, NH4Cl acts as a pore-forming agent, causing disorder and defect carbon to form. BRCAC8502 has a highly porous structure with macropores (20–100 nm) and mesopores (5 nm). The separation of two carbon layers by 0.34 nm aids in the formation of graphite carbon, and EDS shows that C, O, and N are distributed homogeneously. Nitrogen adsorption − desorption studies show that when NH4Cl is added to BRC850, the surface area (396.2 m2 g−1) increases to 458.8 m2 g−1, and 892.1 m2 g−1 for BRCAC850 and BRCAC8502. The presence of pore peaks ranging from 0.6-100 nm indicates that BRCAC8502 has a hierarchical porous structure. The large surface area and the presence of macro- and mesopores facilitate the exposure of abundant active sites, and the mass transfer of reactants and electrolytes, resulting in a large surface area and desirable porosity for oxygen catalysts. According to XRD results, BRCAC8502 has high graphitization and large conductivity, and a higher ID/IG ratio is due to the presence of a large number of defects, which are desirable for electrochemical catalysis, and the creation of pores results in more defects, with the addition of NH4Cl and heteroatom-doping. The enhancement of catalyst performance by defects and conductivity has a limit, as too many defects lead to poor conductivity and thus lower catalytic performance. The surface composition and impact of heteroatom-doping studied by XPS reveals the presence of C 1 s, O 1 s, and N 1 s peaks with N content of 0.94 (BRC850) and 4.41 at% (BRCAC850), indicating that NH4Cl treatment increases the N-content (Fig. 12E). The deconvolution of the N 1 s spectrum results in four peaks due to pyridinic-, pyrrolic-, graphitic-, and oxidized-N, of which the ORR and OER active sites are pyridinic-N (0.60 at%) and graphitic-N (2.00 at%). The presence of 531.2 eV O1 peak, as confirmed by EPR, is due to oxygen vacancies, which improve ORR and OER performance. The distribution of electrons on the surface is effectively controlled by oxygen vacancies, which reduce the adsorption energy of water molecules onto the surface and accelerate a rapid charge transfer, thereby increasing the ORR and OER reaction rate [106]. Thus, the presence of abundant N-doping, O-vacancies, C-defects, and 3D hierarchical microstructure may serve as ORR and OER active sites. The presence of micro-, meso-, and macro-pores on the porous structure of ATRR contributes to the exposure of active sites and facilitates the reactants and ion mass transfer. The CV curves of biomass-based catalysts show a cathodic reduction peak in alkaline electrolyte, with BRCAC8502 having the most positive peak potential of 0.850 V, which is 34 mV higher than Pt/C, and peak potential becoming more positive as surface area increases. The effect of NH4Cl has a greater effect than HT, and the combined effect of NH4Cl and HT results in significantly improved catalyst performance. According to the ORR kinetics studied by LSV, BRCAC8502 has higher ORR activity than BRCAC850 and Pt/C. Eonset (1.06 V) and E 1/2 (0.85 V) are the best reported values for metal-free ORR catalysts. An increase in limiting current density at high rotation rate confirms the diffusion controlled ORR. The Tafel slope of BRCAC8502 (93 mV decade−1) is close to Pt/C (83 mV decade−1), indicating a fast kinetic process for ATRR-derived catalyst along with reliable stability and higher methanol resistance, in comparison to Pt/C. The OER performance of BRCAC8502 studied by LSV shows stable current density when catalyst was coated on gas diffusion layer (GDL), possibly due to improved contact of the catalyst with GDL, whereas GDL does not show any current density for OER. For a current density of 10 mA cm−2, BRCAC8502 requires 1.68 V OER potential, whereas RuO2 requires 1.81 V. The potential difference (ΔE) of the bifunctional catalyst for BRCAC8502 is 0.83 V, which is close to the previously reported bifunctional catalysts but lower than for Pt/C-RuO2 (0.97 V). A biomass-derived catalyst (BRCAC8502) was tested as the air cathode catalyst in a home-made rechargeable Zn − air battery with a polished Zn plate as the anode and Pt/C-RuO2 catalyst (Fig. 12F). The open-circuit potential for BRCAC8502 is 1.44 V, which is very close to 1.46 V for Pt/C-RuO2, indicating nearly equal activity and peak power density of 48.6 and 49.8 mA cm−2 for BRCAC8502 and Pt/C-RuO2, respectively. The Zn-air battery with BRCAC8502 has a stable voltage for 135 h and a specific capacity of 732 mA·h g−1, indicating excellent durability and a large specific capacity. The stable charge/discharge performance outperforms that of many bifunctional catalysts, confirming BRCAC8502′s comparable, if not superior, performance to Pt/C-RuO2. Following battery testing, the BRCAC8502 catalyst was evaluated to understand superior cycle stability, and the nanostructures show no significant change in nanopores and C-defects, indicating its good mechanical strength and structure stability. The improved discharge/charge performance of zinc battery is due to an enhanced pyridine-N and oxygen vacancies that are evenly-distributed on the BRCAC8502 surface. As a result, this simple strategy could be applied to the preparation of N-doped bifunctional oxygen catalysts from biomass waste. It makes use of the rich intrinsic C, N element, numerous active sites and hierarchical structure all at the same time. The active sites and porous structure developed during HT and pyrolysis of ATRR enhances the electrochemical performance of BRCAC8502, and it shows bifunctional activity superior to Pt/C and RuO2 in alkaline medium. The zinc battery built with this catalyst had a higher open circuit voltage, a more stable discharge voltage, good specific capacity, and improved charge/discharge performance. O-vacancies, C-defects, hierarchical 3D porous structure, and N-doping, primarily pyridine-N content and oxygen vacancies, all contribute to this performance. Deriving excellent bifunctional catalysts from plant residues could thus be a novel strategy to aid in the design and development of new bifunctional catalysts. 3.7 Wood Natural wood biomass was used as a carbon precursor in the low-cost synthesis of mechanically strong hierarchical porous catalysts for commercial ESC devices [107,108]. The rich hierarchically porous structure of wood microfibers [109] could be used to produce channels and to prepare “breathable” carbon plates [35,110] by utilizing the mechanical strength and natural microchannels present in natural wood. There is currently no study on the direct conversion of biomass into porous electrodes for ORR/OER-based devices. The abundantly available raw wood, which contains cellulose/hemicellulose microfibers and lignin, serves as a carbon precursor for the synthesis of mesoporous N-doped carbons (N/HPC) with large surface area and rich hierarchical pores via a simple method involving recyclable enzyme-catalyzed hydrolysis of cellulose microfibers in the generation of numerous micropores. Raw wood is composed of semi-crystalline cellulose as the basic fibrils; hemicellulose to crosslink the cellulose fibrils, and lignin to generate stiffness [108], resulting in a strong, hierarchical porous structure for transporting ions, water, and O2 during metabolism [109]. The direct conversion of raw wood into N-doped porous carbon is depicted schematically in Fig. 13 (A). Wood is digested overnight in cellulase aqueous solution, forming numerous shallow nanopores on its surface. The enzyme-modified wood is carbonized in N2 before being pyrolyzed with NH4Cl in N2, resulting in a 3D N-doped catalyst with a large number of hierarchical pores. Hydrolysis results in the formation of pores. SEM results confirm that the transformation process preserves the shape and strength of the starting wood, as well as the well-preserved anisotropic 3D architecture with pores aligned in parallel and long channels in the vertical direction after pyrolysis. It has high conductivity in both the vertical and horizontal directions, with values of 70.4 and 46.3 S m−1, respectively, and raw wood in bulk can thus be transformed into porous carbon catalysts. The treatment of raw wood with enzyme and pyrolysis greatly aids in the evolution of the porous structure. Enzyme treatment produces a rough surface, and cellulose hydrolysis creates shallow nanoholes on the pore walls, but intrinsic macropores remain even after carbonization at 700 °C. As seen in SEM images at various magnifications (Fig. 13(C) and (D)), numerous mesochannels are present on the surface of pore wall of the enzyme-treated wood carbon, and the subsequent release of ammonia gas during NH4Cl pyrolysis creates more nanopores on the surface. The intrinsic macropores and treatment-induced micropores are stable up to 1000 °C. TEM (Fig. 13(E)) confirms the interconnected nanoporous structure of N/E-HPC-900, while the corresponding elementary mapping shows a uniform distribution of N on the carbon skeleton (Fig. 13(F)). The porosity of N/HPC indicates the presence of both micro- and mesopores, with a surface area of 1039 m2 g−1 for N/E-HPC-900 and 746 m2 g−1 for the sample without enzyme treatment. XPS confirmed the N-doping of the carbon skeleton, with three peaks observed at 397.9 (pyridinic-N), 400.0 (pyrrolic-N), and 401.3 eV (graphitic N) [111], and N/E-HPC-900 with more pyridinic-N sites and mesochannels was the best for the OER process. N/E-HPC-900 used as the cathode material had the highest N-content (3.7 at%) (Fig. 11(B)) and was found to be highly ORR and OER active, with an onset potential 0.988 V and a kinetic current density higher than Pt/C. The hierarchical porous structure promotes O2 mass diffusion, resulting in higher current density and a 4e− reduction pathway, and a higher stability and methanol resistance. The OER activity of N/E-HPC-900 has a lower onset potential and a larger Tafel slope than RuO2. The high OER performance is due to the low population of active species and the moderate coverage of O* and OH* on pyridinic-N [112]. After 20000 s, the OER durability of N/E-HPC-900 showed a 10.1% decrease in OER current compared to 36.6% for RuO2. The N/E-HPC-900′s high durability is due to its higher degree of graphitization and level of N-doping. Because of the presence of numerous ORR and OER active sites and a hierarchical porous structure that facilitates mass diffusion, N/E-HPC-900 with higher ORR and OER activity is a good cathode catalyst for Zn-air batteries. It also outperformed carbon-based electrodes during testing in MABs, DMFCs and PEMFCs. A rechargeable Zn-air battery with an open circuit voltage of 1.49 V was assembled using N/E-HPC-900 in the cathode and zinc acetate in KOH as the electrolyte (Fig. 13(G)). The charge/discharge polarization curves for N/E-HPC-900 (Fig. 13(H)) have a small voltage gap suitable for charge–discharge capability, and the peak power density of 192.7 mW cm−2 is higher than that of Pt/C + RuO2 (154.9 mW cm−2). Bulk raw wood-derived N-doped hierarchical porous carbons are prepared via an enzyme treatment and NH4Cl pyrolysis. The formation of nanopores on micropore walls results from the selective hydrolyzation of cellulose in raw wood. This increased the exposure of catalytic active sites to reactants while preserving the mechanically strength of the cross-linked network of wood. Numerous ORR-active graphitic-N and OER-active pyridinic-N sites were doped into the carbon network at 900 °C, resulting in oxygen catalysts with excellent bifunctional performance in an alkaline medium. This template-free approach is ideal for the scalable conversion of low-cost natural wood biomass into bifunctional oxygen catalysts. 4 Critical discussion 4.1 Recent advances in biomass-based catalyst In addition to the biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts discussed in section 3, composites of biomass-derived porous carbons and metal/alloy/metal-oxide nanoparticles are also used as ORR/OER catalysts. Though the primary focus of this review is on biomass-derived self-doped porous carbons, yet some recent studies on composites composed of biomass-derived porous carbons and metal-based nanoparticles for use as bi- and tri-functional catalysts in MABs and RFCs have also been included for completeness. Composites containing biomass-derived carbons and metal-based nanoparticles exhibit high bifunctional activity as well. Some composites based on representative biomass, including seaweed [113], chlorella [114], cattle-bone [115], peanut shells [116], expired milk powder [117], peach gum [118], egg white [119], agarose [120], bamboo sticks [121], and privet fruits [122] have been briefly discussed in this section. As bifunctional ORR/OER elctocatalysts for MABs, 3D hybrid nanoaerogel composites containing Ni/NiO/NiCo2O4 nanoparticles and seaweed biomass-derived N-doped carbon nanotube aerogels were prepared using an alginate-derived biomass conversion approach. The high performance of bifunctional electrocatalysts is attributed to the use of nanoparticle catalytic center for charge transfer and a 3D hierarchical mesoporous network for efficient mass transfer [113]. The chemical composition (N and C precursor) and structure of biomass chlorella have been used to synthesize N-doped bamboo-like CNTs that encapsulate cobalt nanoparticles as bifunctional oxygen catalysts. The high proportion of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N, the synergistic effect of Co nanoparticles and N-doped carbon, and the 3D framework structure all contribute to the higher bifunctional activity [114]. Composites containing Co3O4 nanoparticles dispersed on N-doped hierarchically porous carbon derived from cattle-bones exhibit excellent bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalytic activity. Because of its higher bifunctional activity and lower ΔE of 0.810 V, it may be a promising air electrode for Zn-air batteries [115]. A low-cost and efficient bifunctional oxygen catalyst consisting of porous carbon derived from waste peanut shells and co-doped with nitrogen and NiFe alloy has been reported for use in Zn-air batteries.
