The catalyst had a 0.81 V overpotential, which was 20% lower than the Pt/C and IrO2 system. The charging/discharging polarization curves of a Zn-air battery with this composite as the electrode were superior, as was the high peak current density and long-term cycle stability [116]. By embedding Ni-Fe oxide (NiFeO x ) nanoparticles on N and P doped porous carbons derived from carbonized expired milk powder, an efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst was prepared. The composite demonstrated high ORR/OER catalytic activity and was used as air electrodes in Zn-air batteries. The ORR and OER catalytic activities were improved by N and P doped carbons and mixed metal oxides, respectively [117]. N-doped carbon nanosheets were prepared using peach gum biomass containing C, O, and H, as a carbon precursor to create conductive carbon matrix, and melamine after converting to graphitic carbon nitride as a nitrogen source and template. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles were then embedded to produce Co/N-Pg nanosheet composites for ORR/OER [118]. It demonstrated high ORR catalytic activity and a low OER overpotential in alkaline media due to the synergistic effects of cobalt oxide nanoparticles and Co-N-C species, and Co/N-Pg coated porous paper was used as air electrode in Zn-air batteries, exhibiting high peak power density and good stability [118]. A nanocomposite containing 3D egg white derived N self-doped hierarchical porous carbon embedded with cobalt-iron-phosphide (CoFeP) nanodots, and having honeycomb-like morphology and large surface area was prepared as an efficient bifunctional ORR/OER catalyst for non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries [119]. A simple and scalable sol–gel strategy was used to synthesize composite of Fe-Ni2P particles on N and P dual-doped porous carbon nanosheets derived from green biomass of agarose. The composite demonstrated excellent bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalytic performance in alkaline medium. More catalytic active sites were created when Fe atoms were added into Ni2P, whereas biomass-derived porous carbon provided a larger surface area and a higher graphitization degree [120]. Bamboo sticks with inherent cellulose structure were used to synthesize self-supporting bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts comprising of uniformly distributed NiFe alloy nanoparticles on N-doped carbon fibers derived from bamboo sticks biomass. The hierarchical porous structure of bamboo sticks, combined with the synergistic effect of NiFe nanoparticles and N-doped carbon, produced high ORR/OER bifunctional activity with ΔE of 0.71 V [121]. It demonstrated high peak power density, round-trip efficiency, and excellent cycle stability as a self-supporting highly porous bifunctional air electrode in liquid Zn-air battery. Carbon fibers with interconnected porous structure are created by the presence of cellular fibers in raw bamboo sticks with abundant macropore structure. The high conductivity of N-doped tubular carbon fibers results in a larger surface area and more accessible active sites, facilitating mass transport during oxygen reactions. NiFe nanoparticles and N-doped carbon both help to improve elctrocatalytic performance [121]. Aside from composites containing metal-based nanoparticles as one component, metal-free heteroatom-doped nanocarbons (MFHNC) are also promising because of being resistant to CO poisoning and oxidation of intermediate species [122]. MFHNC’s tunable surface properties and high electron mobility make it an excellent choice for electrocatalytic reactions. In addition to heteroatom doping, intrinsic edge and topological defects have an impact on the electrocatalytic performance of carbon materials. Defect-rich N-doped carbon sheets like graphene were prepared from fallen privet fruits (biomass) as a carbon precursor as highly active electrocatalysts for Zn-air batteries. The heteroatom doping modulates the electronic structures and surface chemistry of the carbon framework, improving catalytic performance, whereas structural defects alter the local charge distribution, resulting in asymmetrical electronic states that catalyze the ORR/OER process. The synergistic effect of N-doping and topological defects results in high ORR activity and reasonable OER performance. Thus, graphene-like carbons perform well as an air–cathode in MABs, opening a new avenue for the scalable synthesis of biomass-based metal-free electrocatalysts for next-generation energy devices [122]. The recent review of details on the design and tuning of the activity of bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts may be useful in developing efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts [38]. In addition to biomass-based composites as bifunctional oxygen catalysts, some biomass-based trifunctional (ORR/OER/HER) catalysts composites have been reported. As trifunctional catalysts, composites containing biomass, such as willow catkins [123], citric acid [47], carrot [124], golden shower pod [125], cellulose [126], and mushroom [127] have been studied. Composites of Co3N4 nanoparticles with willow catkins biomass-derived N-doped hollow hierarchical porous carbon nanotubes have been used to create an effective, low-cost, and sustainable trifunctional electrocatalyst. The original inherited micron tubular structure of biomass is preserved and contributes to the formation of hollow micro/mesoporous hierarchical structures, while doped N and Co3N4 nanoparticles provide additional active sites for electrochemical oxygen reactions [123]. A gas-foaming strategy for the one-step carbonization of NH4Cl and citric acid was reported for synthesizing N-doped carbon nanosheets. This method yields nanosheets with numerous micropores and edge defects, as well as a distinct very thin nanosheet and a large surface area (1793 m2 g−1). According to DFT calculations, the most active ORR/OER/HER sites are carbon atoms at the armchair edge and adjacent to the graphitic-N [47]. Waste carrots with an interconnected 3D macroporous structure and a high C, O, and P content were used as a phytomass source, and nickel nanoparticles were decorated on P-doped carbon using a simple, environmentally friendly method [124]. Because of the synergistic effect of Ni atoms and P-doping, large surface area, charge transfer resistance, and OH− diffusion, nickel nanoparticles affect electrical conductivity and ORR/OER/HER active sites [124]. N-doped porous carbons synthesized from golden shower pod biomass using a solvent-free method exhibit high trifunctional (HER, OER, and ORR) performance in alkaline medium [125]. For the synthesis of 3D porous electrocatalyst, CoN x C was anchored in 3D N-doped porous carbon nanofibers derived from the pyrolysis of bacterial cellulose, an environmentally friendly biomass, and bimetal ZIFs [126]. The multifunctional catalyst exhibited excellent ORR, OER, and HER activity with low overpotential. As an air cathode in Zn-air batteries, the catalyst displayed high cycling stability and power density. This excellent performance is due to the synergistic effect of the 3D porous carbon nanofibers network and abundant CoN x C active sites, which provide fast ions and mass transport as well as a large electrode/electrolyte contact area [126]. For a new class of photo electrochemical catalyst for multifunctional (ORR/OER/HER) electrocatalytic reactions, a simple and novel route to synthesize isotype and anisotype heterojunction from biomass has been proposed [127]. Mushroom, a renewable biomass with intrinsic N and P in content, is used and does not require any external heteroatom precursor. This electrocatalyst produced a high power density and cyclic stability in a Zn-air battery. The use of a p-n heterojunction to prepare a photo-responsive bifunctional oxygen catalyst is a novel idea [128]. The contacts among n and p type materials will promote electron and hole transfer, improving the elctrocatalytic performance of the heterojunction material and opening a new avenue for a combined photo- and electro-chemical technology for energy conversion [127]. The increasing use of biomass-derived carbons as anodes in batteries has led to fundamental studies on understanding the actual performance of batteries and its correlation with biomass science, thermochemical processing, properties, and electrochemistry. The interplay between biomass, bioprocessing, electrochemistry, and materials science for the development of batteries can lead to better utilization of sustainable and environment-friendly biomass materials and it has recently been reviewed [129]. A road map for using agricultural biomass as anode material by reducing impact of battery production on environmental by lowering the dependence upon fossil fuels, greenhouse emissions and water uses is also provided. Out of different dimensional materials, 2D carbons with unique properties are promising catalysts or electrode materials for efficient energy devices. As their fossil-based synthesis is not environmentally friendly, so there is need for developing biomass-based green, sustainable, and economical route for 2D porous carbon materials. The recent strategies for synthesizing 2D carbons from biomass and biological materials, and their applications in batteries, supercapacitors, and ORR electrocatalysts has been reported [130]. The merits/demerits of each method and future perspectives are provided to select a suitable synthetic strategy. Due to extensive use of 2D materials in energy technologies, the strategies for tailoring electronic structure of 2D materials and applications of nanosheet as electrocatalysts in ORR, OER, and HER has been reported [45]. It can help in the design of simple protocols for rechargeable MABs, RFCs, electrolyzers, and other practical devices. 4.2 Importance of bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts for metal-air batteries and fuel cells Bifunctional oxygen catalysts are used in MABs and RFCs, and some recent advances in Li-O2 and Zn-air batteries, and fuel cells are discussed here. The use of oxygen from air as cathode in metal (Li and Zn)-air batteries results in high theoretical energy density [50,131,132] and batteries with high (>3500 Wh kg−1) theoretical specific energy are in the limelight but their poor cyclic stability, low power and high polarizations for ORR (discharge) and OER (charge) is not desirable. Hence bifunctional catalysts are required to improve ORR and OER kinetics [133] and for this intermediate species should have adsorption energies near the top of ORR and OER volcano plots. As electrocatalysis (ORR and OER) can improve the performance of MABs and RFCs, so nanocarbons doped with multi-heteroatoms along with proper combination and configuration can be a good approach for enhancing electrocatalytic activity [50]. The suitable design of nanocarbons, understanding the mechanism, and optimization of the ORR/OER performance is very helpful for devices. Tuning the surface properties, such as doping, edges, defects, and functional groups along with large surface area and micro/meso porosity can contribute to improved performance [50]. Applications of bifunctional oxygen catalysts in Li-O2 batteries, reversible fuel cells, and Zn-air batteries have recently been reported [50,57,60,64,133]. The role of material design and optimization of bifunctional oxygen activity in Zn-air batteries has been explained for developing future materials [57]. In MABs, electricity is generated by the oxidation of metal and reduction of oxygen taken from ambient air and Li, Zn, Al, and Na as metal electrodes [134]. Due to high corrosion resistance, low-cost and large reserves, Zn is a better electrode, with Zn-air batteries having theoretical energy density five times than Li-ion batteries and significantly lower cost can be a promising next-generation energy storage device. As high ORR/OER overpotential limit the energy efficiency of Zn-air batteries so metal-free bifunctional oxygen catalysts are required on the air electrode to lower overpotentials, and to enhance the performance. The ORR/OER active sites in bifunctional catalysts have different requirements and hence regulation of the intrinsic activity is very crucial for good performance. The design of bifunctional oxygen catalysts should thus concentrate on active materials with higher activity and desirable structural controls for optimum performance. The intrinsic activity can be tuned by doping heteroatoms in carbon nanomaterials that modifies the electronic structure by varying the chemical environment [57]. The accessibility of active sites to oxygen, electrolyte and electrons can be enhanced by a proper structural design, and hierarchical pore structure improves the utilization efficiency of active sites. ΔE of 0.65 V has been reported in 0.1 M KOH in practical Zn-air batteries [135] and ΔE was only 0.68 V in a liquid Zn-air battery with bifunctional oxygen catalysts as air electrode with best round-trip efficiency (64.8%). As large ORR/OER overpotential affect the performance for commercial applications, so activity of bifunctional oxygen catalysts should be improved. The sluggish kinetics at the cathode and high ORR/OER overpotential in aqueous Li-O2 batteries requires bifunctional catalysts with the intermediate species having adsorption energy near the top of ORR/OER volcano plots [133]. Due to the different role of catalysts in aqueous and non-aqueous media, same electrocatalyst may not work for both type of Li-O2 batteries. Based on electrochemical and computational studies, the edge sites in graphitic carbons have been found to be more favorable for lowering the overpotential, in comparison to basal plane [60]. N-doping in carbon nanotubes lowers the overpotential in alkali medium and increases the electron transfer number from 2 to 4 [51]. Zn-air battery with N/F co-doped graphdiyne show higher power density and further studies are required to understand the origin of intrinsic activity arising out of graphdiyne doping with heteroatoms. In addition, the presence of chlorine in N/S co-doped biomass-derived carbon show high power density in proton membrane fuel cell in acidic media. Heteroatom doping, composition tuning, hierarchical porous structures, and creating defects are some of the practical and effective strategies for designing carbon-based ORR catalysts that match Pt/C performance [64]. The isolated single atoms doping of Fe, Co, and Ni into carbon materials has recently emerged as new single-atom-doped ORR electrocatalysts [136]. Their excellent conductivity contributes to the electrochemical process, large surface area and porous structure promotes the mass transfer and provides contact sites. Structural defects act as highly efficient ORR active sites, while doping optimizes the intrinsic activity of the active sites. Single atom catalysts are thus a new class of catalysts with the isolated dispersion of metal atoms on the substrate and looks very promising due to the distinct electronic effect, uniformity of active sites and optimum use of metal [137]. The design of catalysts should be flexible but mechanically strong and should match the electrode geometry for optimum performance in practical devices [57]. Recently, the use of bifunctional oxygen catalysts in RFCs that combines a fuel cell and a water electrolyzer was reviewed [138]. Their development and commercialization, however, are hampered by the lack of efficient bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts, which are critical in improving oxygen reactions but generate complex oxygen species. As a result, high catalytic activity, long-term stability, and strong corrosion resistance in acidic/alkaline media and at high potential are critical for their use in commercial RFCs. Despite the fact that nitrogen and co-doped porous carbons have been reported as bifunctional oxygen catalysts, their complex synthesis and use of toxic chemicals limit their scalability. As previously discussed, various types of biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen catalysts could be a viable alternative for these energy storage and conversion devices. 4.3 Material design, perspectives and future directions 4.3.1 Material design The design of carbon catalysts is hampered because the precise active sites and the transformation process of the oxygen molecule are unknown. The gap between theoretical prediction and experimental performance can be bridged by designing a suitable microstructure using a simple methodology [60]. Bifunctional catalysts have different requirements for the ORR/OER active sites. Thus, in order to achieve excellent ORR/OER performance, effective materials must be sought and intrinsic activity should be properly controlled [57]. Despite the fact that many promising materials have been prepared using controlled strategies, current carbon catalysts do not match the performance of commercial precious metal-based catalysts [64]. The design strategies for improved bifunctional ORR/OER activity should include the synthesis of carbon catalysts with abundant active sites with high bifunctional activity [57]. By lowering the activation barriers of the ORR and OER, smart electrocatalyst design can result in high bifunctional oxygen activity and excellent performance in a variety of devices [50,57]. Correlations between different active sites, porosity, hybrid structures, and good catalytic performance could be the guiding principles for the material design of efficient oxygen catalysts for specific applications [50]. The following strategies for designing efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are proposed: Heteroatom doping - Different roles are played by doping carbon materials with heteroatoms and defect structures in the ORR/OER catalytic process [50,57]. The heteroatom doping modifies the electronic structures and elements at the surface of the carbon skeleton, improving catalytic performance [122]. Because single precious metals cannot have multifunctional (ORR and OER) activity at the same time, fabricating heteroatom-doped carbons with excellent multifunctional catalytic performance and durability is a promising commercial option [127]. However, because single heteroatom doping does not result in increased catalytic activity in acid, co-doping can be used to boost activity. The presence of chlorine improves the ORR of N- and S-doped carbon in acidic media due to the synergistic effect of N and Cl due to the redistribution of the energies of intermediates, allowing for a lower overpotential. The use of multi-heteroatom doping in carbon materials improves catalytic activities while also providing multifunctional activities [50]. Heteroatoms with large radius have also been doped, but it is unclear whether these atoms enter into carbon lattice and bond to carbon atoms properly [60]. Defect engineering - Defect engineering can boost ORR performance with an edge site and the topological defect acting as different types of defect in carbon-based catalysts. The overpotential in graphene, rich in defects and containing sufficient edge-induced topological defects, is primarily lowered by the five-seven carbon ring [58]. Structural defects affect the local charge distribution, resulting in an asymmetrical electronic-state area. The electrocatalytic activity is improved by optimizing the adsorption states of reaction species [139]. The electrocatalytic activity due to various defects is in the following order: topological defects > edge-doping > bulk-doping, with the N-free topological defect at the top of both the ORR and OER volcano plots [50]. Combined doping and defect engineering - As previously discussed, both heteroatom-doping and defect engineering enhance the catalytic activity by altering the electronic structure and spin densities. Simultaneous defects and doping to design efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts by doping (single/multiple) heteroatoms at specific defect (edge, pore, and topological) sites could be a much more effective strategy for achieving optimum electrocatalytic performance for metal-free biomass-derived oxygen catalysts [140]. Machine learning can efficiently resolve the possibilities of numerous combinations due to the random distribution of defects and dopants in porous carbons. Morphology - Carbon materials with similar dopants but different morphologies exhibit different catalytic performance because dopant content modifies intrinsic catalytic activity while morphology influences mass transfer [60]. Carbon’s morphology (micro/meso) and surface functional groups can aid in the inclusion of active components, uniform dispersion of nanoparticles, and increased utilization efficiency [50]. Catalysts with hierarchical pore structure are required for mass transport, as macropores serve as for gas transport channels and numerous mesopores act as ORR and OER reactions regions. Rich active sites on the catalyst’s surface help in exposing more active sites to the reactants. The high conductivity of the catalyst facilitates electron transfer, while the interface resistance is reduced due to strong interactions of the catalyst particles with current collectors [57]. The morphology should be designed so that the majority of exposed active sites have access to oxygen feedstocks and electrolytes. The catalyst’s morphology should result in a large surface area and hierarchical porosity. The electronic structure of active sites at the catalyst surface could be tuned to control the ORR/OER volcano plot, resulting in high bifunctional activity [57]. Structure - The distinct structure and functional groups present at the surface enable nanocarbons to modulate the electron structures of active components, thereby optimizing catalytic activity [50]. To synthesize various carbons catalysts with desirable properties, efficient and scalable methods that can simultaneously optimize surface functionalities, porous structures, and functional groups are required [50]. Because of the distinct 3D architecture that favors the mass transfer of oxygen and electrolyte during the OER/ORR, the electrocatalytic activity of 3D porous carbons is greatly enhanced [126]. Noble carbons with ordered structures that are resistant to oxidation can also be synthesized by the self-assembly of nucleobases and are useful in applications [130]. Aside from biomass, biological molecules such as guanine can be used to derive nanostructured materials with better structure control at the molecule level. Hydrogen bonding or π-π stacking interactions guide the self-assembly of diverse nucleobases, resulting in supramolecular aggregation and functional nanostructure. The carbonization of nucleobases results in highly sp 2-conjugated 2D carbon as well as heteroatom doping [130]. The structure should be tuned to increase surface area, mass diffusion, and electron transport, exposing more catalytic active sites [57]. Adsorption energy of intermediates - Because the adsorption energies of intermediates are critical in the activation barrier of each reaction, a catalyst with adequate adsorption energy is required. The bonding of intermediates (OOH*, H*, etc.) to the catalyst surface should be neither too weak nor too strong, as this can lead to the top of volcano plots for maximum activity. Because the adsorption energies of intermediate species are affected by the electron structure of the catalyst surface [50], designing bifunctional oxygen catalysts should bring the tops of two volcanos plots closer together. The unifunctional ORR and OER catalysts can be mixed to produce bifunctional electrocatalyst [57], but a large quantity of catalyst is required to attain performance matching catalysts with intrinsic bifunctional activity [57]. Another method for designing catalysts focuses on controlling the stability of different intermediates by constructing 3-D catalytic active sites that bind various reaction intermediates in other ways, such as alloying, doping, or defects [41]. The activity of the ORR/OER catalyst [38] could be improved by increasing the number of active sites exposed or by increasing their intrinsic activity. When designing an effective bifunctional oxygen catalyst, the nature of the active site should be determined firstly. In-situ characterization techniques can provide more detailed information about intermediate and active sites, which can be used to guide subsequent catalyst design [38]. The design of bifunctional oxygen catalysts is a critical and challenging topic in energy and materials research, and more innovative studies are thus required for basic research and practical applications [57]. 4.3.2 Perspectives and future directions In general, the perspectives on bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are: [57] (i) Identify the primary factors influencing catalyst activity, such as intrinsic activity, amount, and accessibility of active sites, which should be prioritized when designing a bifunctional electrocatalyst. (ii) Deeper understanding of the reaction pathway, identification of active sites, and interface behavior in the ORR/OER reaction process. (iii) Mechanically strong flexible catalysts with a strongly coupled interface for excellent performance [57]. These can be achieved by employing the following approaches: Multiple heteroatom-doping - Nitrogen doping induces positive charge on carbon and as a result adjoining carbon atoms become catalytic active sites, whereas doping with B and P, that have lower electronegativities than that of carbon induces B and P heteroatoms to act as active sites instead of carbon. Thus, multiple heteroatom doping of carbon materials results in creating new active sites that depend upon the concentration and location of heteroatom dopants, and provide higher electrocatalytic activity. Similarly, as single N doping cannot improve acidic ORR, dual doping is required. Recently, chlorine doping in N/S co-doped biomass-derived carbon resulted in a high-power density in fuel cells. The high ORR activity in acidic conditions of nonmetal co-doped and nonmetal-metal co-doped carbon materials with porous structures and large surface areas can lead to breakthroughs in future fuel cells [60]. Sp-dominated carbon materials - Graphdiyne, a sp-dominated carbon, outperforms commonly studied sp 2-dominated carbon materials in catalytic performance [141]. Because of a novel sp-N nitrogen species at the sp-hybridization carbon site, N-doping of graphdiyne increases ORR activity [142] with alkaline performance comparable to Pt/C and higher ORR activity in acidic media. The kinetic current density in acid and alkali is affected by the sp-N content. The acidic ORR activity was increased by the selective pyridinic-N doped graphdiyne. At a high current density, a Zn-air battery demonstrated higher power density performance with N/F co-doped graphdiyne [143]. However, the origin of intrinsic activity in graphdiyne from heteroatoms is unknown and require further investigation [60]. Carbon nanomaterials based on graphdiyne can also aid in understanding the strong relationship between microstructure and catalytic activity. Theoretical studies/reaction mechanism - To address the drawbacks of the correlation between different simple sites and electrochemical activity, big data calculations and atomic level DFT methods should be developed. To establish the electron catalysis theory, the effect of heteroatom doping in metal-free carbons and surface adsorption on electrocatalytic performance should be studied [60]. Theoretical studies to better understand the ORR/OER mechanism highlight the importance of scaling relationships between reactive intermediates involved in oxygen reactions. This disadvantage can be overcome by decoupling the binding energies of various intermediates, such as by stabilizing OOH* relative to OH* [144]. In order to design efficient oxygen catalysts, it is necessary to have a thorough understanding of the interface and the related kinetics [38]. The identification of mechanisms and active sites is required for rational and effective catalyst design, and the results of theoretical studies should match experimental conditions. Calculations at the atomic level will be more beneficial in understanding the role of catalytic active sites [64]. Computational and simulation techniques are very powerful for understanding the origin of active sites on the surface of catalysts, and these studies can be very useful for developing highly active, stable, and selective catalysts for clean energy technologies [145]. New synthetic methods/protocols - New and simple synthesis methods, as well as advanced characterization, are required for efficient ORR/OER catalysts for specific applications [50]. As a result, standard protocols are required for synthesizing and testing the activity, durability, and performance in actual devices. For industrial use, low-cost, simple, and scalable production of homogeneous electrocatalysts with controlled structure and surface chemistry are desired. To achieve this and obtain reproducible results, the synthesis methods and testing conditions should be standardized so that the activity of electrocatalysts can be compared under different conditions and media. The synthesis methods should be simple, efficient, controllable, and scalable [130]. In-situ characterization - In-situ characterization is very useful in understanding the mechanism of formation of biomass-derived 2D carbons, and in-situ TEM can monitor real-time changes in skeleton structure. Combining experimental and theoretical studies can lead to improved design of high-quality 2D carbons with uniform morphology, large aspect ratio, high-level of in-situ heteroatom dopants, and well-developed porous structure. In-situ characterization techniques (SPM and XPS under ambient pressure and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy) can provide more information about intermediate species and active sites, and may thus be the first step in designing efficient bifunctional catalysts [38]. Composite materials – Several carbon materials exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity for either ORR or OER. Another strategy for developing bifunctional oxygen catalysts could be a composite of these two [133]. In general, an ideal active site on the ORR volcano peak may not be on the top of the OER volcano. Intrinsically, the same single site cannot be active for both the ORR and the OER at the same time. In bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, both types of sites must be properly integrated into a composite [145]. Different materials can exhibit catalytic activity for either ORR or OER, and combining these as composites can provide a new strategy for developing highly effective bifunctional oxygen catalysts. Composites are expected to be efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts as they comprise of two separate components - one good for ORR and the other for OER [38]. Heterojunctions - Because it is difficult to achieve efficient multifunctional activity on a single catalyst while also being stable and durable, a simple and practical approach is to develop heterojunction materials having strong interactions among heterogeneous components as stable catalysts with higher multi-activity [127]. The electronic structure and surface properties of isotype (n-n type) and anisotype (p-n type) heterojunction materials could be modified using heterostructure engineering. Because of the large conductivity and stability of the nanocrystals, the high surface area, numerous defects, and fast charge transfer at the heterojunction interface, the isotype heterojunction decorated with cobalt nitride nanocrystals on N-doped carbon acts as an efficient multifunctional (ORR/OER/HER) catalyst with good performance and higher stability. As a result, high performance Co, N-containing multifunctional carbon-based catalysts having isotype (n-n type) and anisotype (p-n type) heterojunctions were constructed. In the n-n type, mushroom-derived hierarchical porous carbon was combined with nonstoichiometric active species, allowing many ways to tune the catalytic and photoelectrochemical behavior of catalysts [127]. The presence of reduction/oxidation catalysts as well as the proper energy band structures of two catalysts, results in an increase in the photoelectrochemical catalytic activity and stability [127]. This approach leads to a new and simple way to develop biomass-derived isotype and anisotype heterojunctions for multifunctional catalytic activity, leading to photoelectrochemical multifunctional catalysis [127]. In addition to above, performance can be improved by designing catalysts with novel concepts that have effective interactions between N, C and transition metals during precursor processing and heat treatment [145]. In a 3D architecture, a large surface area with mesoporous structures can increase the density of active sites, resulting in higher current density. The use of graphene as a template can provide additional possibilities to enhance the catalyst activity. A thorough understanding of the actual active sites is required for increasing the activity and durability of catalysts continuously [145]. The bonding mechanism and optimal N and C structures are still unknown [145]. More research is needed to elucidate other details of the electrode–electrolyte interface that are still poorly understood. It is necessary to investigate the kinetics and reaction barriers of the main elementary steps during proton/electron transfers under relevant reaction conditions [41]. The mechanism of activity and applications of electrocatalysts in practical devices must be thoroughly understood and is a major challenge [50]. The development of bifunctional oxygen catalysts is critical and very challenging in materials and energy research, and more innovative work is required to promote basic research and commercial applications [57], and will play an important role in future energy technologies [50]. 5 Conclusions The two most important oxygen reactions (ORR and OER) at the center of renewable clean energy conversion and storage technologies require efficient catalysts to overcome the sluggish kinetics and large overpotential. Because of the presence of different steps, intermediates, and different binding energies between active sites, the activity for both reactions is generally not identical, and thus good ORR catalysts are not always good for OER and vice versa. Thus, bifunctional oxygen catalysts with multi-active sites involving multiple redox centers are required for oxygen reactions. Heteroatom-doped carbon materials derived from renewable and sustainable earth-abundant biomass may emerge as efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts due to a low-cost synthesis by a simple process in which heteroatom-doping and structural defects provide active centers for both OER and ORR. We discussed the ORR/OER mechanism for conventional catalysts, N-doped carbon materials, and biomass-derived catalysts, as well as their performance, in this review. Biomass-derived bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with heteroatoms in the intrinsic biomass composition have been reviewed. Furthermore, recent studies on composite (bi- and tri-functional) electrocatalysts with biomass-derived porous carbons as one of the components have been discussed briefly. Recent advances in biomass-derived bifunctional catalysts as well as their importance in MABs and other devices has also been discussed. Perspectives and future directions for the design of materials for advanced bifunctional oxygen electroatalysts are been included. Recent progress on heteroatom-doped carbon materials based on earth-abundant biomass as bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts for renewable energy technologies is summarized in this review. We reviewed the most recent developments in heteroatoms self-doped porous carbons derived from biomass materials with heteroatoms in their intrinsic composition. To develop heteroatom self-doped hierarchically porous carbons as bifunctional oxygen catalysts with good performance for various electrochemical devices such as MABs and RFCs, the use of external toxic heteroatom precursors is avoided. Bifunctional oxygen catalysts self-doped with heteroatoms are good because the dopant that depends on the nature and choice of biomass can induce structural defects and provide active sites, thereby improving ORR/OER performance. The main focus of the review is on biomass with carbon and heteroatoms in their intrinsic composition, which avoids the use of toxic chemical precursors for heteroatom doping, making the synthesis low-cost, green and environmentally friendly. Thus, biomass-derived porous carbons have the potential to be future bifunctional catalyst materials for efficient and stable oxygen electrode catalysts, and their ease of synthesis is crucial for their commercial use in a variety of renewable energy technologies. Recent advances in biomass-based catalysts, including composites of conventional catalysts with biomass-derived porous carbon materials as bi- and tri-functional catalysts have also been reviewed. The significance of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts in MABs and RFCs has also been emphasized. The ORR/OER mechanism for bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts based on some conventional materials and heteroatom-doped porous carbons has been discussed. The scaling relationship of the oxygen-based intermediates limits the bifunctional activity. The shape of the ORR and OER volcano plots can be changed by regulating the electronic structure of the ORR/OER active sites, resulting in increased bifunctional activity. By designing the structure correctly, more active sites can be made accessible to the oxygen, electrolyte, and electrons. However, the origin of intrinsic activity caused by heteroatom doping is still being debated due to a lack of understanding of the exact active sites and the 4e− ORR pathway. The performance of current bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, as well as their advantages and disadvantages has been discussed. Future directions and materials design perspectives have been proposed. Because of a synergetic charge-transfer effect, co-doping of carbon nanomaterials significantly enhances the catalytic activity. Advanced carbon nanomaterials, such as graphdiyne, can be useful in studying the correlation between micro-structure and electrocatalytic activity. To produce heteroatom-doped carbon-based electrocatalysts with the proper structure and surface chemistry for industrial applications, a scalable process, such as cost-effective ball-milling, is also required. The development of bifunctional oxygen catalysts derived from biomass is thus a major and challenging topic in this field. The rational design principles and strategies discussed in the review may be useful in future studies on bifunctional oxygen catalysis, motivating more focused studies to significantly contribute to academic and industrial progress. Satpal Singh Sekhon received his doctoral degree in Physics from Punjabi University, Patiala, India. He worked as a Professor of Physics and Applied Physics at Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, India and at The University of the West Indies, St Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago. He also worked as Brain Pool Scientist at Fuel Cell Research Centre, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea. He is currently a University Honorary Professor at Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, India, and an Invited Scientist under Brain Pool program of NRF Korea, at Sangmyung University, Cheonan, South Korea. He has been awarded MRSI Medal by Material Research Society of India for his outstanding contribution in the field of Materials Science and Engineering. He has published over 100 research papers and was recently listed among the Top 2% scientists of the world (Energy) in a global list compiled by Stanford University scientists. His current research interests include heteroatom-doped metal free electrocatalysts based on carbon nanomaterials and biomass for fuel cells and other energy technologies. Jaeyoung Lee is currently Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST) Prominent Professor and the Vice Director of the Ertl Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis. He obtained his Ph.D. degree in 2001 at Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG and FU Berlin, Germany under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Gerhard Ertl (2007 Nobel Laureate). He stayed at KIST and RIST (POSCO) as a senior scientist between 2002 and 2007. His research field spans to fuel cells, water electrolysis, CO2 and NH3 electrocatalysis, Li-S battery, CDI and AI Electrochemistry. Jin-Soo Park received his doctoral degree in Department of Environmental Engineering from Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST), Republic of Korea in 2004. He worked as a postdoctoral researcher at Fuel Cell Research Center, Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) from February 2004 to April 2005. He worked as a Senior Researcher at the same center from May 2005 to August 2009. He joined in Department of Green Chemical Engineering, College of Engineering, Sangmyung University, Republic of Korea in 2009, promoted to Assistant Professor in 2011, Associate Professor in 2015, and Full Professor in 2020. His research interests mainly focus on in the materials and processes for electrochemical engineering such as proton exchange membrane fuel cell, water electrolysis, reverse electrodialysis, capacitive deionization, redox flow battery, etc.

coredata.dc:description: Oxygen electrode catalysts are important as inter-conversion of O2 and H2O is crucial for energy technologies. However, the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR and OER) are a hindrance to their scalable production, whereas scarce and costly Pt and Ir/Ru-based catalysts with the highest electrocatalytic activity are commercially unviable. Since good ORR catalysts are not always efficient for OER and vice versa, so bifunctional catalysts on which OER and ORR occurs on the same electrode are very desirable. Alternative catalysts based on heteroatom-doped carbon nanomaterials, though showed good electrocatalytic activity yet their high cost and complex synthesis is not viable for scalable production. To overcome these drawbacks, biomass-derived heteroatom-doped porous carbons have recently emerged as low-cost, earth-abundant, renewable and sustainable environment-friendly materials for bifunctional oxygen catalysts. The tunable morphology, mesoporous structure and high concentration of catalytic active sites of these materials due to heteroatom (N)-doping could further enhance their ORR and OER activity, along with tolerance to methanol crossover and good durability. Thus, biomass-derived heteroatom-doped porous carbons with large surface area, rich edge defects, numerous micropores and thin 2D nanoarchitecture could be suitable as efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts. In the present article, synthesis, N-doping, ORR/OER mechanism and electrocatalytic performance of biomass-derived bifunctional catalysts has been discussed. The selected biomass (chitin, eggs, euonymus japonicas, tobacco, lysine and plant residue) except wood, act as both C and N precursor, resulting in N self-doping of porous carbons that avoids the use of toxic chemicals, thus making the synthesis a facile and environment-friendly green process. The synthetic strategy could be further optimized to develop future biomass-based N self-doped porous carbons as metal-free high performance bifunctional oxygen catalysts for commercial energy applications. Recent advances and the importance of biomass-based bifunctional oxygen catalysts in metal-air batteries and fuel cells has been highlighted. The material design, perspectives and future directions in this field are also provided.
